questions.text: Which of the following structures are not pierced during epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
During epidural anaesthesia, the local anaesthetic is injected into the epidural/extradural space and the dura is not pierced in epidural anaesthesia.

Structures pierced during epidural anaesthesia (in that order):

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space

The dura mater is not pierced during epidural anaesthesia. The needle is advanced through the ligamentum flavum and into the epidural space, which is located just outside the dura mater.

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

Structure / Space  Terminal extent 
Spinal cord at birth  L3 upper border 
Spinal cord at 2 years  L1 lower border 
Adult Spinal cord  L1 lower border  
Filum terminale  1st coccygeal segment 
Filum terminale internum , Dural sac S2 lower border 
Filum terminale externum  1st coccygeal segment 
Piamater  1st coccygeal segment 
Subarachnoid sheath and space, Subdural space  S2 lower border 
Cervical enlargement  C3-T2 spinal segments 
Lumbar enlargement  L1-S3 spinal segments 

Related Pearl: High yield points in epidural anaesthesia

  • Epidural space lies between dura and ligamentum flavum
  • Dura is not penetrated
  • The site of action of epidural anesthesia is nerve roots
  • Tuohy needle is used for epidural anesthesia
  • Methods to identify epidural space:
    • Loss of resistance technique
    • Hanging drop technique – Gutierrez's sign (sudden sucking of a drop in epidural space)
  • Methods to confirm epidural anesthesia
    • Test dose with 3cc lidocaine with 15mcg adrenaline (1:2,00,000) - Intrathecal injection will produce spinal anesthesia (lidocaine) that should be rapidly apparent. Intravascular injection will produce significant tachycardia 20% above baseline (adrenaline).
    • Durant’s sign – rapid injection of the drug in epidural space causes an increase in rate and depth of respiration
    • Westpal sign – absence of knee-jerk after epidural anesthesia
  • Anesthetic of choice in epidural anesthesia during labor - Bupivacaine
  • Epidural narcotic preferred over epidural local anesthesia because of the absence of motor paralysis
  • Drugs used for epidural analgesia- Morphine, Fentanyl
  • Epidural opioids act on dorsal horn substantia gelatinosa. It may cause pruritis and respiratory depression
  • Drug not given in central neuraxial block or caudal block- Remifentanil
  • Walking epidural- Ultra low dose epidural used especially for labor (only sensory blockade)
  • Complication of Epidural anesthesia -Total spinal anesthesia
  • Not a complication of epidural anesthesia –DIC, Headache
  • During epidural anesthesia- sudden hypotension is due to the drug entering subarachnoid space

Related Pearl: Differences between Spinal and Epidural anesthesia

Dosing Single dosing With the catheter in situ, multiple dosing and continuous infusions possible
Onset of action Rapid (2-5 minutes) Slow (15-20 minutes)
Density of block More dense Less dense
Hypotension Rapid Slow

questions.text: Infectivity is also known as?
questions.solution:
Infectivity is also known as the secondary attack rate.

Infectivity is the ability of an infectious agent to cause a new infection in a susceptible host. In diseases that are directly transmitted, it is measured by the secondary attack rate, which is the proportion of susceptible individuals that develop the infection after exposure to a primary case. It measures the communicability of the disease.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/ (Total number of susceptible close contacts).

Once a person gets infected, the time interval between invasion and appearance of the first sign or symptom is called as incubation period. During incubation, the agent multiplies in the host and builds up till it is sufficient to present as a disease.

As it is difficult to precisely calculate the incubation period, the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is used to calculate the incubation period. This is called serial interval.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Incidence rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time ) x 1000

Incidence rate of spells of sickness = ( Number of spells of sickness starting in a specified period /Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time ) x 1000

Attack rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time /Total population at risk during the given time ) x 100

Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period/Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts ) x 100

Prevalence = ( Number of all cases (new+old) of a specified disease at a given point in time/ Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

questions.text: What is the pattern of inheritance in neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance in neural tube defects(NTDs) is multifactorial inheritance.

Multifactorial inheritance refers to traits that are caused by a combination of inherited, environmental, and stochastic factors. NTDs and a number of other congenital malformations, such as cleft lip and palate, can recur in families, but inheritance for the majority of affected individuals does not occur in a straightforward, mendelian inheritance pattern. In this situation, multiple genes and environmental factors together likely contribute to the pathogenesis.

These include the following: 

Children (congenital malformation)

   Adults

Pyloric stenosis

Neural tube defects

Congenital heart defects

Congenital dislocation of hip

Cleft lip and cleft palate

 Diabetes Mellitus

 Hypertension

 Coronary heart disease

 Gout

 Schizophrenia

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug used to control seizures in a child presenting with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug to control the seizures in febrile seizures is a benzodiazepine like midazolam or lorazepam.

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors:

Major:

  • Age  less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever  less than 24 hr
  • Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

 Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis includes oral clobazam for 3 days during the fever episode, if the febrile seizures recur at the rate of ≥3 seizures in 6 months, or ≥4 in 1 year.
  • Continuous prophylaxis with sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used for failed intermittent prophylaxis and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures.

Note:

  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

questions.text: A patient presents with repetitive episodes of heartburn and chest pain. What is the most common condition that causes these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from dyspepsia and the most common cause of dyspepsia among the given options is esophagitis.

Dyspepsia refers to symptoms of epigastric pain, burning, postprandial fullness or early satiety, sometimes with heartburn condition based on the symptoms is esophagitis. Gastroesophageal reflux which causes esophagitis is the common cause of dyspepsia.

Esophagitis is the most common cause of heartburn and non-cardiac chest pain. The reflux of gastric acid into the lower oesophagus is the most frequent cause of esophagitis. The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower oesophagal sphincter relaxation.

Clinical significance: Reflux esophagitis → chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) → Barrett oesophagus → adenocarcinoma

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

The most commons in GIT:

  • Most common congenital intestinal atresia: Imperforate anus
  • Most common true diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum
  • Most common site of ischemia: Colon
  • Most common site of fistulization: Esophagus
  • Most common site of GI Polyp: Colorectum
  • Most common malignancy of GI tract: Adenocarcinoma colon
  • Most frequent cause of esophagitis: Acid reflux
  • Most common benign tumor of esophagus: Leiomyoma
  • Most common esophageal cancer in India and worldwide: Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Most common esophageal cancer in Western countries: Adenocarcinoma
  • Most common type of chronic gastritis: Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
  • Most common malignancy of the stomach: Adenocarcinoma
  • Most common site of extranodal lymphoma: Stomach
  • Most common mesenchymal tumor of the stomach: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
  • Most common tumor of the small intestine/appendix: Carcinoid

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf, initially after walking a distance of 400m later 200m over the last 6 months. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of peripheral arterial disease which has worsened over time. This patient who prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain now has rest pain.

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) presents as intermittent claudication (crampy pain in the muscles). As the disease progresses, claudication distance decreases, and pain occurs even at rest called ischemic rest pain. Rest pain is due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. The pain is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot due to the loss of the gravitational effects on perfusion pressure. It may be lessened by hanging the foot down. 

Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on the raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

The initial investigation done is an ABI. Further investigation is done with Doppler imaging, duplex scan, and digital subtraction angiography. Rest pain is seen when ABI becomes <0.5. 

Other options:

Option A: Sciatica - The patient complains of pain radiating down the back of the thigh and calf. Sciatica can either be because of inflammation of the sciatic nerve or because of compression of one of the roots constituting the sciatic nerve

Option B:  Neurogenic claudication occurs with changes in the position of the back such as bending forward and straightening. It takes more time to be relieved by rest (more than 5 minutes). In spinal stenosis, there is an abnormal narrowing of the central canal, the lateral recesses, or the intervertebral foramina to the point where the neural elements are compromised.

Option C: Patients with venous claudication have some form of venous diseases like varicose veins, edema and skin changes due to chronic venous diseases like pigmentation, eczema or ulcers.

 

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent  OGTT(75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours of glucose at 180 mg/dl. Which among the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.solution:
Since her values are more than the normal limits with a 75 g OGTT she is having gestational diabetes and the next step in the management is to admit her and start insulin.

The glucose tolerance test is considered the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus and insulin is the drug of choice for the treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus. It does not cross the placenta and tight glycemic control can typically be achieved.

Diagnosis of GDM with 75 g OGTT according to IADPSG is made if any one of the following are met:

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: ≥180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hours: ≥153 mg/dl

The initial management of GDM is maternal nutrition therapy with diet and exercise. Insulin therapy is started if :

  • Fasting plasma glucose levels persistently ≥95 mg/dl or the 2-hour postprandial plasma glucose ≥120 mg/dL in women with gestational diabetes treated with maternal nutrition therapy.
  • Glucose levels on OGTT are in the range for overt diabetes.

Since this question does not have the option of Maternal nutrition therapy, the best step would be to start her on insulin.

The starting dose is typically 0.7 to 1 unit/kg/d and is given in divided doses. A combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin may be used.

50% of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening & revaluation between 4-12 weeks postpartum.

Earlier, a two-step approach was used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result for this test were then subject to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. This has now been replaced by the one-step approach that omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: Signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the anatomical distribution of a tumor and are due to hormones released from the tumour tissue is known as?
questions.solution:
Signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the anatomical distribution of a tumor and are due to hormones released from the tumour tissue is known as paraneoplastic syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Parathyroid adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism and the Tc99m sestamibi scan is used for diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. It is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands.

Other options:

Option A: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is not commonly used to image the parathyroid glands

Option B: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.

Option D: Multiphase CT imaging has become widely utilized to localize the disease. It gives both anatomical as well as functional information about the parathyroid glands. The disadvantage is the higher radiation dose when compared to others.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. An X-ray of her skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
  • Urinalysis: positive for Bence-Jones proteins
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia, osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins, and Bence Jones proteinuria make multiple myeloma the most likely diagnosis.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia elevated ESR, Hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20% plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically:(CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT.
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is at least 5 mm or greater in size.

Note:

  • The presence of at least one of these markers is considered sufficient for a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, regardless of the presence or absence of symptoms or CRAB features.
  • Each of these markers has been shown to be associated with an approximately 80% or higher risk of developing myeloma-related organ damage within two years.

 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 30 g/L and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: Identify the marked sign that is seen during 8 weeks of pregnancy.
questions.solution:
The sign seen in the 8th week of pregnancy giving a dusky bluish discolouration of the anterior vaginal wall is known as Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. Chest X-ray was done and given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray depicts multiple large, well-circumscribed, round pulmonary metastases that look similar to cannonballs. Hence it is known as cannonball metastasis that is seen in lung metastasis.

The most common primaries to result in pulmonary metastases in adults include:

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Colorectal carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma
  • Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger and the swelling reaches down to the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A swelling that reduces when pressing through the deep inguinal ring suggests a case of indirect inguinal hernia.

Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia. A femoral hernia passes through the femoral triangle whereas an umbilical hernia protrudes through the umbilicus.

A direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach's triangle. The boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle are:

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

The test being performed in the above image is 3 finger test or Zieman’s test which is used to differentiate groin hernias.

After reducing the hernia, The examiner places his index finger on the deep inguinal ring, middle finger on the superficial inguinal ring, and ring finger over the saphenous opening. Now the patient is asked to cough or to hold the nose and blow.

Interpretation: When the impulse is felt on the,

  • Index finger: The given case is one of the indirect herniae.
  • Middle finger: The given case is one of the direct herniae.
  • Ring finger: The given case is one of the femoral herniae.

questions.text: A COVID patient requires oxygen therapy.Which of the following cylinders should be used to provide oxygen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Colour of the shoulder of oxygen cylinder in India is white, and the body is black. 

Maximum pressure in the oxygen cylinder is around 2000 psig.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with sudden onset increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24, pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO2- 52 mmHg, and HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of COPD with ABG showing respiratory acidosis. The next step for this patient would be to start non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists.
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

If initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures. This decrease in minute ventilation causes progressive hypercapnia, which is however permitted to a certain extent for the benefit of the patient (commonly known as permissive hypercapnia).

The severity of COPD assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is of a secondary follicle, also called an antral follicle.

Development of ovarian follicles: 

At birth, the ovarian cortex contains numerous primordial follicles which contain primary oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flat follicular cells. Most of these follicles degenerate in the prepubertal life and are called atretic follicles. At puberty, around 20 primordial follicles get activated in each menstrual cycle. Out of these 20 primordial follicles, only one follicle is dominant which reaches maturity and releases the oocyte during ovulation. 

The different stages of development of the primordial follicle are: 

a) Primary follicle:

  • Follicle cells change from flattened cells to cuboidal and the stromal cells surrounding the follicle differentiate into spindle-shaped cells called 'theca externa'.
  • The oocyte increases in size and secretes a proteoglycan material around it which forms the layer called 'Zona Pellucida' which is seen between the plasma membrane of the oocyte and the granulosa cells. 

b)Secondary follicle(Antral follicle):

  • The primary follicles continue to increase in size and the granulosa cells multiply.
  • Numerous cavities coalesce to form a single fluid space called antrum.
  • The granulosa cells envelop the oocyte to form a structure called Cumulus oophorus.

c) Tertiary follicle (Graffian follicle):

  • Numerous secondary follicles are formed but only one tertiary follicle develops while others regress and become atretic follicles.
  • As the antrum draws the fhe follicle increase in size and expands to a diameter of 2 cm to become Graffian follicle.
  • The oocyte and the surrounding granulosa cells called corona radiata break away from the follicular wall and float in the follicular fluid.
  • The primary oocyte completes its first meiotic division to form the secondary oocyte and a polar body.
  • The secondary oocyte is arrested in the metaphase of the second meiotic division until fertilization takes place.
  • The follicle ruptures to release the oocyte which is captured by for the fimbriae.

d) Corpus Luteum:

  • The remainder of the follicle after ovulation is called the Corpus luteum. It synthesizes a carotenoid pigment called lutein which gives it a yellowish colour.
  • If the oocyte is not fertilized then corpus luteum degenerates 12-14 days after ovulation to become corpus albicans.
  • If fertilization occurs then the hCG produced by the trophoblast maintains the corpus luteum. It releases progesterone, estrogen, and relaxin, and regresses at around 8 weeks when the placenta takes over.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of phyllodes tumour or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumour is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes presents as a large tumour with an unevenly bosselated surface. The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture.

Phyllodes tumours usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. It is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some having low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

This tumour does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare. Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant type- Mastectomy

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign, solid, encapsulated, and biphasic tumour consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined glands. It is a slow-growing tumour and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases. Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a rapid onset of disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache, vomiting, amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, acromegaly, and infertility. On examination, she has bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of excess prolactin and growth hormone along with features of raised intra-cranial tension. The most likely diagnosis is a mammosomatotrope adenoma of the pituitary. 

Prolactinomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. They are usually found in adults. They may be functioning or non-functioning. Based on the size, they can be called microadenomas if <1 cm in diameter and macroadenomas if ≥1 cm in diameter. 

The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumour
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia

Excessive GH secreted before puberty results in gigantism. Acromegaly occurs when excessive GH is secreted after puberty (after fusion of long bone epiphysis).

Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Other manifestations seen in GH excess are cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, etc.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal resection is the preferred surgery.

Other options:

Option A: Corticotroph adenoma secrete ACTH. They present with features of Cushing's disease. 

Option B: Gonadotroph adenoma secrete FSH and LH. They can present with  polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), infertility, menstrual irregularities, ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) in women, and testicular hypertrophy and sexual dysfunction in men

Option D: Gliomas are neoplasms that originates from glial cells. They present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, seizures, and in more advanced cases weakness or altered mental status.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is not a component of the qSOFA score. 

qSOFA scoring is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting as it does not require laboratory values.

The qSOFA assigns one point for each component and suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met.

  • Altered mental status (GCS <15)
  • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths/min.

A qSOFA score of ≥2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged ICU stay.

SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. This includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analog called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. (So, the patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging).
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner. 
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Areas of normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity, and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract (FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems)
  • Brown fat (FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production)
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

Related Pearl: Half life of radio isotopes

Radioisotope Half-life
Cobalt 60 5.2 years
Iridium 192 74 days
Iodine 131 8 days
Iodine 125 60 days
Iodine 123 13 hours
Iodine 132 3 hours 
Cesium 137 30 years
Technetium 99m 6 Hours
18 FDG 110 minutes
Radon 222 3.8 days
Radium 226 1600 years
Strontium-89 50.5 days
Strontium- 90 28 years
Phosphorus 32 14 days

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in case of esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in esophageal varices in a patient with liver cirrhosis is hypovolemic shock due to variceal bleed/hemorrhage.

Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock and to some degree is a component of all other types of shock.

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

(eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

(eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling 

(eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

(eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock.

(eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency)

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, body temperature of less than 37 degrees, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
This child with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths/min has tachypnea/fast breathing without any danger signs has pneumonia according to IMNCI guidelines. The next best step of management is to administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home.

The treatment for pneumonia for a child between 2 months and 5 years of age is oral amoxicillin and home care advice.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 

 Danger signs:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

Tachypnea or Fast breathing is defined based on the age and respiratory rate:

Age of child Rate
<2 months 60 breaths/min
2-12 months 50 breaths/min
1-5 years 40 breaths/min

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is breast milk deficient in?
questions.solution:
Breast milk is deficient in vitamin K.

Therefore infants have to be supplemented with vitamin K to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains many antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the baby's optimum growth as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

Breastmilk is also deficient in vitamin D and exclusively breastfed infants can develop vitamin D deficiency unless adequately supplemented.

Human milk is a rich source of vitamin C and contains around 5-15mg/100cal. Vitamin C is found in higher levels in breast milk than in cow milk.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination, the left breast appears as shown in the image below. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with breast abscess has not responded to multiple attempts of aspirations. The next best step in this scenario is to perform incision and drainage.

The given scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The initial management of breast abscess includes aspiration of abscess along with supportive measures like a breast support garment, cold compression on the breast and analgesia to aid in symptomatic relief. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding. But her aspirations have been unsuccessful and thus incision and drainage have to be the next step in the management of this patient.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of the lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to a retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscesses.

It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage are performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just a superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of the breast or inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 It occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

 Image below shows mastitis of the breast:

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presented with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery.

The bleeding may be either

  • Revealed - Blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix. Or,
  • Concealed -Blood accumulates between the detached placenta and uterus. Or,
  • Mixed

Risk factors for abruption placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. The haemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This compromises fetal circulation leading to fetal distress.

 Depending upon the degree of placental abruption and its clinical effects, the cases are graded as follows:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate


Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very close to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition. Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe which occurs in later stages. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.

In preterm labour, fetal movements are not compromised. Hydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Indications of PCNL:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

  • Haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy: 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 2 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.Cystine stones are very hard stones as a result of disulphide bonds and do not fragment with ESWL. Other stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL include cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones.

ESWL is only 45-60% effective in the treatment of large stones. It causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially in cases of insufficient disintegration.

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal haemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse  (a german word, which means 'street of stones'). The most common site of the column of stone fragments obstruction is the distal ureter, followed by the proximal ureter and mid ureter. The postoperative image is attached below.

 

Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

These are generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. The most significant complications relate to injury to the ureteric mucosa or wall and include ureteric perforation and extravasation, avulsion of the ureter and ureteric stricture. 

 

Open surgery: A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. 

In extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated open/laparoscopic surgery is used.

questions.text: What is the minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores?
questions.solution:
The minimum external pressure that leads to the formation of pressure sores is 30 mm of Hg.

Pressure sores also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. Thus an external pressure of >30mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are:

  • Ischium
  • Greater Trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral followed by medial)
  • Occiput

A staging system for the description of pressure sores devised by the American National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel.

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. It can be done through good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure dispersion cushions, or foams. The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical treatment of pressure sores mainly involves wound management. The pressure sores should be adequately debrided and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC).VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation in chronic wounds and ulcers. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction(example-extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh). Faecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases depending on the site of the ulcer, being prone to urine or faecal contamination.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium, for the past 2 months. Abdominal palpation reveals splenomegaly. His hemogram and peripheral smear results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hemogram:

Hb - 10 gm/dL

WBC count - 1,65,000/cu.mm (Leukocytosis)

Platelet count - 3 lakhs/mm3

Peripheral smear: 

Metamyelocytes - 15%

Promyeloblasts - 30%

Myeloblasts - 45%
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing a garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with a peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%)

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, What is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with diarrhea, muscular weakness, and hypokalemia not responding to treatment is most likely due to hypomagnesemia.

The major cause of hypomagnesemia in this scenario is severe diarrhoea/gastrointestinal loss which in turn worsens the hypokalemia. In such cases, hypokalemia can not be corrected unless the underlying hypomagnesemia is addressed. 

Treatment failure in hypokalemia due to hypomagnesemia is mediated by two mechanisms:

  • ↓ Magnesium → inhibits Na+/ K+ - ATPase activity → ↓ influx of potassium into the cell → secondary kaliuresis.
  • ↓ Magnesium → decreased block of ROMK (renal outer medullary K+ channel) potassium efflux channels → increased potassium secretion by distal nephron

Therefore in the presence of hypomagnesemia, hypokalemic patients are clinically refractory to potassium supplementation therapy.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. The following are various causes of hypokalemia:

  • Inadequate intake
    • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN
  • Excessive potassium excretion
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Medications 
  • Potassium losses
    • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea)
    • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) 
  • Metabolic
    • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy

Clinical features 

  • Weakness and paralysis
  • Intestinal ileus
  • Risk of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias
  • Broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation are most marked when serum K+ <2.7 mmol/L
  • Sodium chloride and bicarbonate retention lead to metabolic alkalosis

Management includes potassium supplementation with concurrent cardiac monitoring. Treat hypomagnesemia by supplementation. High dose propranolol if due to excess sympathetic activity

Other options:

Option B: The clinical features of hyponatremia are predominantly neurological as a result of the development of cerebral edema. Patients usually present with nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, brainstem herniation, and coma.

Option C: The clinical features of hypermagnesemia are dose-dependent. 

  • >2 mmol/L - vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade.
  • >4 mmol/L - refractory hypotension, progressive weakness leading to respiratory paralysis and coma. Although hypermagnesemia causes muscle weakness, the question asked is the cause of treatment failure in hypokalemia.
  • >10mmol/L - dilated pupils, bradycardia, PR, QRS, and QT prolongation.

Option D: The clinical features of hypernatremia are neurological. The most frequent manifestation is altered mental status ranging from confusion and lethargy to deep coma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a stimulus for vasopressin secretion?
questions.solution:
An increase in plasma osmolarity stimulates vasopressin (aka Antidiuretic hormone) secretion. 

Osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus rapidly detect the change in the osmolarity of extracellular fluid and they control the secretion of ADH.

The two magnocellular neurons of the hypothalamus which synthesize ADH are supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei. Five-sixth of ADH is produced by supraoptic nuclei and one-sixth by paraventricular nuclei. 

ADH exerts its antidiuretic action by activation of  V2 receptors and insertion of aquaporin 2 into the luminal side of the collecting duct.

Whenever blood pressure and low blood volume are reduced as in a situation like a hemorrhage, ADH secretion is increased. This results in fluid reabsorption by the kidney and restores the blood pressure and blood volume to normal.

Nausea is a potent stimulus for ADH secretion. 

Increased ADH Decreased ADH

Increased plasma osmolarity

 Decreased plasma osmolarity
Decreased blood pressure Increased blood pressure
Decreased blood volume Increased blood volume
Nausea Drugs: Alcohol, clonidine
Hypoxia  
Drugs: morphine, nicotine  

Related Pearl: Types of vasopressin receptors and their functions

Receptor Localization Functions
V1a
  • Vascular smooth muscle
  • Platelets
  • Hepatocytes
  • Myometrium
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Platelet aggregation
  • Glycogenolysis
  • Uterine contraction
V3/V1b 
  • Anterior pituitary
  • ACTH release
V2
  • Basolateral membrane of collecting tubule
  • Vascular endothelium
  • Vascular  smooth muscle
  • Upregulation of Aqp2
  • vwF & factor 8 release
  • Vasodilation

questions.text: The image below shows an image of the anus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a smooth swelling on the perineum near the anal opening suggestive of perianal abscess.

Anorectal abscess refers to a collection of pus in the anal or rectal region. More commonly seen in men. Anorectal abscess originates from an infection arising in the cryptoglandular epithelium lining the anal canal. Fistula-in-ano, Crohn's disease, diabetes and immunosuppression are some conditions leading to abscess formation.

Anorectal abscess presents as a painful, throbbing swelling in the anal region with constitutional symptoms like fever. 

There are four types of anorectal abscesses:

  1. Peri-anal (most common)
  2. Ischio-rectal 
  3. Inter-sphincteric
  4. Supra-levator

Treatment:

  • Most of them can be drained under local anaesthesia as an outpatient procedure in the clinic or emergency room.
  • Larger, more complicated abscesses may require drainage in the operating room. A skin incision is created, and a disk of skin is excised to prevent premature closure. No packing is necessary, and sitz baths are started the next day.

Pilonidal sinus refers to non-infected, midline openings in the natal cleft overlying the coccyx. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected and is seen more in men, usually after puberty. Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling and discharge at the base of the spine. Constitutional symptoms such as fever and fatigue are usually absent. The primary sinus may have one or many openings, all of which are strictly in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

The image given below shows a pilonidal sinus in the natal cleft(midline opening).

questions.text: You are administering an 8-month-old infant with vitamin A supplements over the course of 2 consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
This 8-month-old infant should receive 1,00,000 IU of vitamin A orally for 2 consecutive days.

Vitamin A stores in the body last 6-9 months. So a preventive strategy involves administering it to children to prevent the development of its deficiency.

  • For infants between 6-12 months - 100,000 IU orally
  • For a child above 12 months - 200,000 IU orally is given every 6 months.

The same dose of Vitamin A is repeated the next day in case of deficiency.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU in 9 doses given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5 years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-11 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the following finding shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows palmar erythema which is not caused by a hypo-estrogenic state.

Palmar erythema is a condition due to increased dilation of surface capillaries in the hand. Vasodilation is mainly due to increased estrogen levels in the blood. The redness is blanchable, symmetrical, non-painful, non-itchy, and slightly warm. The centre of the palm is usually spared. 

There is a physiological increase in estrogen during pregnancy.  Liver cirrhosis causes inadequate hepatic metabolism of steroid hormones leading to a hyperestrogenic state. The exact cause is not fully understood in the case of rheumatoid arthritis.

Causes of palmar erythema:

  • Primary:
    • Hereditary
    • Pregnancy 
    • Idiopathic
  • Secondary:
    • Liver disease: Alcoholic cirrhosis, Wilson's
    • Endocrine: Thyrotoxicosis, Diabetes
    • Autoimmune: Rheumatoid arthritis, Kawasaki disease,
    • Positioning 
    • Drug-induced palmar erythema.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. Examination findings are given below. The most likely diagnosis in this man is?
questions.solution:
The image above shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen at the margins of the bald patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata.

It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. Follicular orifices may appear as yellow dots on dermoscopy.

Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune disease that causes non-scarring hair loss.

Other options: 

Option A: Tinea capitis (as shown in the images below): The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans. 

 

Option B: Kerion (T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes) is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation.

Option D: Androgenic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumour of the ovary in the reproductive age group?
questions.solution:
A benign teratoma or dermoid cyst is the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group. It is also the:

  • Most common benign tumor of ovary diagnosed in pregnancy
  • Most common germ cell tumor (overall)
  • Most typical tumor to undergo torsion.
  • Bilateral in 10-15% cases.

It consists of a Rokitansky’s protuberance, which is a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands along with teeth & bones can be seen. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological study – known as Struma Ovarii. The most common tissue elements found are ectodermal derivatives.

questions.text: A patient is having loose stools around 20 per day and his urine frequency is reduced now. Which of the following laboratory values is seen in the patient?

choices.text: BUN:Cr >40:1, Urine Na <40, FENa <1%, Urine Osmolality >500
BUN:Cr >20:1, Urine Na <20, FENa <1%, Urine Osmolality >500
BUN:Cr >20:1, Urine Na <20, FENa <1%, Urine Osmolality >250
BUN:Cr >40:1, Urine Na <20, FENa <1%, Urine Osmolality >250

questions.solution:
This patient is having prerenal azotemia due to dehydration from loose stools. The laboratory values consistent with the diagnosis of prerenal azotemia include BUN:Cr >20:1, urine Na <20, FENa <1%, and urine Osmolality >500.

The following can cause prerenal azotemia :

  • Decreased circulating blood volume (gastrointestinal hemorrhage, burns, diarrhea, diuretics)
  • Volume sequestration (pancreatitis, peritonitis, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Decreased effective arterial volume (cardiogenic shock, sepsis).

Renal and glomerular perfusion also can be affected by a decrease in the cardiac output due to peripheral vasodilation (sepsis, drugs) or profound renal vasoconstriction (severe heart failure, hepatorenal syndrome, agents such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs [NSAIDs]).

Difference between pre-renal, renal, and post-renal AKI:

  Pre renal  Renal Post renal
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350mOsm/kg <400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 meq/l >40meq/l Variable
FeNa <1 >2 Variable
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1 <20:1
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 <20:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline Muddy brown cast Normal or RBC/WBC

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Marjolin's ulcer?

choices.text: It is seen in sites of chronic wounds or scars.
It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma.
It is radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding Marjolin's ulcer is it rapidly progresses to malignancy.

Marjolin’s ulcer is a term used to describe a rare type of cutaneous SCC (squamous cell carcinoma) which arises in sites of chronic wounds or scars. It progresses to full-fledged SCC gradually. The transformation is slow, with an average latency time of approx 30 years. Since the ulcer occurs in scarred tissue without nerves and vessels, it is painless and radioresistant

The tumour may initially present as:

  • Ulceration
  • Nodules 
  • Rolled or everted wound margins
  • Excessive granulation tissue
  • A rapid increase in size
  • Bleeding on touch.

For the diagnosis, an edge-wedge biopsy can be done. MRI of the part and regional node area is done to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves wide local excision and in case of a large ulcer, amputation is required.

An image of Marjolin's ulcer is below:

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma arising from
    • Long-standing ulcer like venous ulcer
    • Post-burn scar
    • Chronic osteomyelitis
    • Post-radiation ulcer.
  • Slow progression to malignancy (SCC) since it is relatively avascular.
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue.
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue.
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity.

questions.text: A known hypertensive patient is brought to the ER with palpitations and breathlessness. On examination, his BP was 220/140 with signs of encephalopathy. Which of the following is used as a 1st line drug to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a diagnosis of hypertensive emergency. The first-line drug in this scenario is IV nicardipine.

Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD).

Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents.

In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction.

The table below shows the treatment of various hypertensive emergencies.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies
