questions.text: Identify the genetic disorder.
questions.solution:
This patient's picture of short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). Gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure which is hypogonadism.

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here)

  • Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest
  • Amenorrhea (primary), infertility
  • Barr body absent
  • Cardiac defects(bicuspid aortic valve >coarctation of aorta), Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema
  • L: Learning disabilities
  • Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome material is present)
  • Webbed neck
  • Nipples widely spaced
  • Horseshoe kidneys

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems is associated with a baby born to this lady?
questions.solution:
The condition associated with an infant born to a mother with diabetes mellitus is hypoglycemia.

In pregestational diabetes and gestational diabetes mellitus, maternal hyperglycemia causes a higher amount of blood glucose to pass through the placenta into the fetal circulation. It results in fetal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinism. These increased insulin levels continue to persist after delivery which leads to hypoglycemia. Extra glucose in the fetus is stored as body fat causing macrosomia. These newborns are at risk of developing various complications due to fetal hyperglycemia. They are:

  • Gastrointestinal: These infants may demonstrate abdominal distention caused by a transient delay in the development of the left side of the colon due to fluctuations in maternal and fetal glucose resulting in small left colon syndrome.
  • Metabolic: Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
  • Neural: Neural tube defects like caudal regression syndrome, encephalocele, anencephaly 
  • Respiratory: Respiratory distress syndrome, transient tachypnea of newborn, persistent pulmonary hypertension
  • Cardiac: Cardiomegaly, cardiac malformations like a ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels(most specific), truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Haematological: Polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis
  • Others: Hyperbilirubinemia, insulin resistance, diabetes, sudden intrauterine death

questions.text: While performing surgery for acute appendicitis on a 2 year old child the following structure was found 2 feet proximal to ileocaecal junction and it was 2 inches long. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical viignette and image is suggestive of Meckel diverticulum which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel.

The most common true diverticulum is Meckel diverticulum, which occurs in the ileum.

A true diverticulum is a blind outpouching of the alimentary tract that communicates with the lumen and includes all three layers of the bowel wall. Meckel diverticulum occurs as a result of the failed involution of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac.

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • approximately 2 inches in length
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Location 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: A couple presented in the outpatient department with infertility. The husband's semen analysis was normal. The wife reported menorrhagia and a hysterosalpingogram showed a tobacco pouch appearance with distal dilatation of the tubes.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with a hysterosalpingogram showing a tobacco pouch appearance is diagnostic of tubal salpingitis, most likely tubercular salpingitis.

Hydrosalpinx occurs following acute salpingitis. The tubes are retort-shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla and filled with a clear fluid. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to the primary focus. The fallopian tubes are the first to be involved and are bilaterally affected.

It is secondary to hematogenous spread from a primary focus. The ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below.

HSG should not be performed in a suspected case of genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes.

If performed, HSG findings in tubercular salpingitis include:

  • A rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube, Coiling of the tubes
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Tubal diverticula and/or fluffiness of tubal outline.
  • Uterine cavity—irregular outline, honeycomb appearance, or presence of uterine synechia

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Other options:

Option A: Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Option B: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: Which of the following milestones in an infant is achieved at the earliest?
questions.solution:
The milestone which is achieved earliest in the above options is ulnar palmar grasp which is seen by 6 months of age. 

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand-ulnar palmar grasp. 
  • At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm-radial palmar grasp.
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp

18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks

3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle

questions.text:
Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?

G6PD deficiency- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
questions.solution:
Elective splenectomy is done in case of hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is passed down in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis.

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. However, due to the possible adverse effects, it is only indicated in severe cases and after the child attains puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option (A): Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of inherited hemolytic anemia. It is associated with exacerbations after consuming anti-malarial drugs and in periods of oxidative stress. The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells". In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. G6PD deficiency is largely preventable by avoiding exposure to triggering factors.

Option (B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a hemolytic disorder that also presents with pancytopenia and a tendency to form venous thrombi. It occurs due to defective GPI anchors on the red blood cell surface which are normally used to anchor CD 59 (cell-protective proteins) to the surface. These patients can present with episodes of dark brown urine in the morning, anemia, pancytopenia, and recurrent abdominal pain due to thrombosis of abdominal veins. 

Bone marrow transplantation is done for the treatment. Recently humanized monoclonal antibody eculizumab is used.

Option (D): Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Related Pearl: Features of peripheral blood smear in different anemias

questions.text: A 13 year old boy was brought to the child psychiatrist by the parents. The parents reported that child lies frequently at home and in school, misbehaves with the teacher, often bullies the younger kids and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of misbehaving with people , bullying and theft for the last couple of years points towards a diagnosis of conduct disorder.

If it persists beyond 18 years of age it is referred to as anti-social personality disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

Onset of Conduct Disorder:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals show no symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder  
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Oppositional defiant disorder(ODD):

  • Persistent pattern, lasting at least 6 months, of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults, including arguments, temper outbursts, vindictiveness, and deliberate annoyance.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present for 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies to listening to adults
    • Annoys other people quite often

NOTE: Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: Onset before age 10. Severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. The child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreaks.

questions.text: A 53-year-old  patient was brought to the emergency room with altered sensorium and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly and sclerae are icteric. The other examination findings are given below. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with the presentation of altered consciousness, jaundice (scleral icterus), and signs of liver cirrhosis (distended abdomen, hepatomegaly), spider naevi, Terry nails, and the characteristic AST>ALT is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

In alcoholic liver disease, usually the AST: ALT > 2:1. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise while AST levels increase. An AST: ALT ratio >2:1 is suggestive, whereas a ratio >3:1 (as in this patient)  is highly suggestive, of alcoholic liver disease.

Normal levels:

  • Aspartate transaminase (AST) - 10-40 IU/L
  • Alanine transaminase (ALT) - 10-40 IU/L

Other options:

Option B: In acute viral hepatitis, the aminotransferases are often elevated > 500 IU (400-4000 IU/L) due to extensive cell injury.

Option C: In autoimmune hepatitis, aminotransferase levels are elevated and fluctuate in the range of 100-1000 IU/L. Autoimmune hepatitis may present as acute or chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis. Commonly associated symptoms include fatigue, anorexia, pruritis, arthralgias, upper abdominal discomfort, and skin rashes including acne among others. 

Option D: Acute acetaminophen poisoning (paracetamol tablets ingestion).In acute acetaminophen poisoning, the aminotransferases are elevated > 1000 IU and may exceed 10,000 IU/L due to acute hepatocellular injury. 

Liver Function Tests patterns in Hepatobiliary Disorders

Type of Disorder Bilirubin Aminotransferases Alkaline phosphatase

Acute hepatocellular necrosis (viral and toxin-induced hepatitis, acute heart failure)

Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin 

Elevated often, >500 IU/L

ALT > AST

 Normal to <3x normal elevation
Alcoholic hepatitis Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin AST: ALT >2  Normal to <3x normal elevation
Chronic hepatocellular disorders  Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin Elevated but usually <300 IU/L Normal to <3x normal elevation
Hemolysis Increase in indirect bilirubin (85% of total serum bilirubin) Normal Normal
Intra- and extrahepatic cholestasis Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin Normal to moderate elevation Elevated, often >4x normal
Obstructive jaundice Increase in direct bilirubin Normal to a slight elevation  Elevated, often >4x normal

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the above-mentioned clinical presentation is Mallory Weiss tear .

Mallory Weiss Syndrome is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of longitudinal superficial mucosal lacerations (Mallory-Weiss tears). The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed.

It mainly occurs in patients with repetitive forceful retching and vomiting and is associated with heavy alcohol intake. The presence of portal hypertension with oesophagal varices and hiatal hernia may aggravate the condition. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory Weiss tear is conservative, as it usually is self-limiting. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy is done in some cases. Angiographic embolization or high gastrotomy is necessary only in rare cases that don't respond to conservative management.

Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by a tear in the lower third of the oesophagus which occurs when a person vomits against a closed glottis, causing a leak into the mediastinum, pleural cavity and peritoneum. Here all layers are involved.

The patients initially present with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. Clinical features include Mackler's triad

  • Retching
  • Chest pain
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

This catastrophic event produces severe mediastinitis(deranged vitals tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension) and generally requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level < 200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
Gestational sac > 4cm is an indication for surgical management of ectopic pregnancy.  

Management of ectopic pregnancy: 

Expectant management is where only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution.

Indications:

  • Asymptomatic 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
  • Initial serum hCG level <200 mIU/mL
  • Gestational sac size less than 4 cm 
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS

Medical management with intramuscular methotrexate injection, which can be done in single-dose or multidose protocols. The dose for single-dose therapy is 50 mg/m2.

Indications

  • Low initial serum beta-hCG level 
  • Small gestational sac size- 4cm
  • Absent fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable

Surgical management of ectopic pregnancy includes laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy and microsurgical laparotomy. 

Indications

  • Criteria for expectant and medical management are not met
  • Significant pain and hemoperitoneum 
  • Gestational sac ≥4cm
  • Fetal cardiac activity present
  • Beta-hCG >5000 mIU/mL
  • Failure of expectant or medical management

questions.text: A patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma presents to the emergency with abdominal pain. On examination his vitals were HR-122, BP-80/50 mmHg, SpO2-94%, and there were abdominal guarding and rebound tenderness. What is the initial step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Get a CECT abdomen to rule out intraperitoneal bleed
Get a USG FAST to rule out intraperitoneal bleed

questions.solution:
The history of blunt abdominal trauma, hypotension, abdominal guarding, and rebound tenderness is diagnostic of an intra-abdominal bleed. Since he is haemodynamically unstable, the initial management of this patient is to resuscitate him with intravenous crystalloids. 

A patient with blunt abdominal trauma who is haemodynamically unstable needs urgent exploratory laparotomy to control the bleeding. But the initial management and evaluation are directed at ATLS protocols based on Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure, thus the first step is to stabilize him with IV fluids. In a hemodynamically unstable patient with abdominal trauma, the initial step is to start resuscitation with intravenous crystalloids. This helps restore intravascular volume, improve blood pressure, and stabilize the patient's condition before proceeding with further diagnostic evaluations or interventions.

The management of abdomen trauma depends on the hemodynamic status and the examination findings. Some major indications for laparotomy:

  • Peritonitis
  • Hemodynamic instability with positive FAST
  • Hollow organ injury
  • Stab wound with evisceration
  • Shock from uncontrolled bleeding

In a patient with hemodynamic instability and no signs of peritonitis, focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is performed. If FAST is not available, then a diagnostic peritoneal lavage is done. The presence of intraabdominal bleeding on either necessitates further exploration.

If the patient is hemodynamically stable with no signs of peritonitis, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan is done to look for intra-abdominal injuries and decide on the need for operative, nonoperative, or angiographic therapy. In a patient with trauma and signs of peritonitis, an exploratory laparotomy is done. 

The most common organs that are affected in blunt abdominal trauma are the spleen followed by the liver. Blood should be urgently typed and transfused in case of unstable patients with large bleeds when needed.

questions.text: A primigravida delivers a healthy baby via normal delivery. After how many hours should she initiate breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
In this scenario of a healthy mother and infant, breastfeeding should be started within 1 hour.

Breastmilk is the ideal and exclusively food for infants in the first 6 months. It reduces the infant mortality rate, neonatal hypocalcaemia and hypomagnesemia hence  should be started as soon possible.

The standard essential newborn care include:

  • Maintain the airway and breathing
  • Maintain the body temperature and prevent hypothermia
  • Initiate breastfeeding within one hour
  • Cleaning of baby and care to prevent infection
  • Cord care and care of the eyes
  • Administering vitamin K
  • Performing a thoroiugh examination.

 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A man brings his father who became unconscious while working in a field in the hot sun at 42 degrees Celsius in May. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte values were normal. The physician found that the body temperature was 106 F. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient is highly suggestive of heatstroke. The symptom least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating.

Heatstroke occurs due to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. The person fails to lose heat by cutaneous circulation and sweating. It is likely to develop when the body temperature rises to a range of 105°F to 108°F. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, and physical activity

Heatstroke can be:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

It is a medical emergency that leads to homeostatic imbalance. The symptoms include dizziness, abdominal distress, vomiting, delirium, and eventually leading to loss of consciousness. On examination, the skin is dry, hot, and flushed, with a complete absence of sweating (anhidrosis). Other signs seen in heat stroke are tachycardia, Kussmaul-type rapid deep breathing (tachypnea), hypotension, cardiac failure, dizziness, muscle cramping, confusion, and seizures. Heatstroke can cause damage to multiple organ systems, including the brain, kidneys, and liver, which can lead to life-threatening complications. It is essential to initiate rapid cooling and supportive care measures to prevent permanent injury or death. The cooling methods used to treat heatstroke include:

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature >104.9o Fahrenheit (> 40.5 degrees Celsius) help establish the preliminary diagnosis. The body temperature must be measured rectally.

Treatment includes rapidly cooling the body with ice water till the rectal temperature falls below 102oF.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

Related Pearl: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presented with fever, vomiting and right hypochondriac pain that was radiating to the neck. She has had similar on and off episodes in the past.On examination, Murphy's sign is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with positive Murphy's sign is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usually because a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by the stone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include:

  • Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back
  • Fever
  • Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia
  • Jaundice
  • Positive Murphy's sign
  • Positive Boas' sign

Murphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costal margin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line. The patient is then instructed to take deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a ‘catch’ of breath, Murphy’s sign is said to be positive.

Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site where pain is radiated to the back, typically, below the scapula.

An ultrasound scan is sensitive in acute cholecystitis and demonstrates a distended gallbladder with thickened wall, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone, and the sonographic Murphy's sign. The gold standard investigation of acute cholecystitis is hydroxyiminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m ( 99mTc)-a labelled derivative of iminodiacetic acid.

The first-line treatment would be medical conservative management to subside the symptoms. The conservative management includes nil per mouth with intravenous fluid administration, administration of analgesics and antibiotics. 

Other Murphy's in surgery:

Murphy's punch sign: This test is performed by the examiner using the fist to make jabbing thrusts over the costovertebral angle. The test is positive for infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney.

Murphy's triad is associated with acute appendicitis.

  • Pain in the right illiac fossa
  • Vomiting
  • Fever

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.solution:
The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start LMWH. 

Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in people with prosthetic valve. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, and fetal embryopathy if used in the first trimester. LMWH is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin.

Period of gestation Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

 LMWH or UFH
13 to 36 weeks Warfarin
36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery LMWH or UFH
6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)
 (LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin, UFH- Unfractionated heparin)

It is recommended that all women on warfarin switch to LMWH or IV UFH at weeks 34–36. Since giving IV UFH until delivery is difficult, LMWH would be the better option till UFH is started. UFH should be started approximately 24 hours prior to labour induction or caesarean. IV UFH should be stopped once in labour or 6 hours prior to caesarean. UFH should be restarted 4 to 6 hours post-vaginal delivery or 6–12 hours post-caesarean section. Warfarin should be restarted on day 1 postpartum (uncomplicated vaginal delivery) or on day 2-3 if caesarian or bleeding complications occur.

Heparin should be discontinued just before delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then iv protamine sulfate can be given.(Easy reversal of anticoagulation). Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

Other options:

Option B: Unfractionated heparin can also be given instead of LMWH. However, in this case, the better answer is to give LMWH; because, in clinical practice, LMWHs have a long half-life, once-daily dosing, and fewer side effects. If LMWH is unavailable or cost-prohibitive, or if anti-Xa levels cannot be monitored, continuous infusion of UFH can be used as an alternative to LMWH.

Option D: Aspirin 75-100 mg can be given daily during pregnancy. It can be continued in women with mechanical heart valves if needed for other indications.

questions.text: A handwashing awareness session was conducted in a community. The correct sequence of events here is:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events in this health awareness session is: awareness > interest > evaluation > adoption.

 1. Awareness Stage: The individual becomes aware of the innovation. He is exposed to innovation but has only limited information about it. At this stage, he doesn’t give much attention to the new product. 

2. Interest and Information Stage: The individual becomes interested in innovation and tries to collect more information. He tries to know about qualities, features, functions, risk, producers, brand, colour, shape, price, incentives, availability, services, and other relevant aspects.

3. Evaluation Stage: The consumer considers accumulated information and use it to evaluate the innovation and judge the worth of innovation. He compares different aspects of innovation like qualities, features, performance, price, after-sales services, etc., with the existing products to arrive at the decision whether the innovation should be tried out.

4. Adoption Stage: If trial produces satisfactory results, finally the consumer decides to adopt/buy the innovation. He purchases the product.

The four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behaviour laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law Ex: The government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhoea

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the ER after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

The Heimlich maneuver is performed as follows:

  1. Stand behind the person and slightly to one side.
  2. Place your arms around the person's waist.
  3. Make a fist with one hand and place the thumb side against the person's upper abdomen, above the navel and below the ribcage.
  4. Grasp your fist with your other hand and give quick, inward and upward thrusts to the abdomen, using enough force to dislodge the object.
  5. Repeat thrusts until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

Other options:

A) Bag and mask ventilation involves providing breaths of air using a bag and mask to a person who is not breathing adequately. While it may be necessary if the person becomes unconscious, it is not the immediate next step for a conscious individual who is unable to speak due to choking.

B) Endoscopic removal involves using a flexible tube with a camera to visualize the airway and remove the obstructing object. This may be considered if the initial Heimlich maneuver is unsuccessful in dislodging the object.

C) Deliver 5 backslaps and 5 chest compressions: This technique, known as back blows and chest thrusts, is recommended for infants under one year of age in cases of choking. In this scenario with an 18-year-old boy, the Heimlich maneuver is the more appropriate action to attempt to clear the airway obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the part of the bowel in the barium study given below.
questions.solution:
The radiological image given above is barium follow-through of the small intestine and the portion marked is Jejunum.

On the supine radiological examinations, the jejunum characteristically occupies the upper part to the left of the midline, whereas the ileal loops tend to occupy the lower central or right part of the midline. This can be reversed in conditions like malrotation caused by small bowel obstruction.

Plica cirulares is most prominent in the jejunum and it gives the characteristic staked-up appearance of the jejunum in contrast X-ray, CT, or MRI.

The various parts of the bowel in barium follow-through is given in the image below.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the MRI of the brain is the Internal capsule.

The image below shows parts of the brain in an axial section of an MRI.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • Anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb
  • Retrolenticular/retrolentiform portion
  • Sublenticular/sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, a lesion here produces confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.

Genu carries fibers of the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemi-sensory deficits.

The retro-lenticular part carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

The sub-lenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibers.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of internal capsule.

  • Anterior choroidal artery ( branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery
Sublentiform part

  • Posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive tissue in our body?
questions.solution:
The most radiosensitive tissue in our body is bone marrow. 

The most radiosensitive:

  • Tissue - bone marrow
  • Blood Cell - Lymphocyte
  • Stage of cell - G2-M interphase
  • Cell type - Rapidly dividing cells
  • Ocular structure - Lens
  • Retinal structure - Rods>Cones    

Least Radiosensitive: 

  • Tissue - nervous tissue
  • Blood Cell - platelet
  • Stage of cell -  S phase
  • Cell type - Quiescent cells
  • Ocular structure - Sclera
  • Retinal Layer - Ganglion cell layer  

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a 2-year-old child gives a history of completing required antenatal vaccinations during her previous pregnancy. Which of the following would you recommend for her current pregnancy?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of TT
Give a booster dose of Td

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a mother who was vaccinated in her previous pregnancy 2 years ago, a booster dose of Td (tetanus and adult diphtheria) is recommended.

All pregnant women must be vaccinated with 0.5 ml, intramuscular Td in the upper arm to prevent neonatal and maternal tetanus.

  • Unimmunized women should receive two doses of Td vaccine with the first dose given as early as possible. The second dose should have at least one month gap and be given at least 3 weeks before delivery to allow sufficient time for developing antibodies.
  • Previously immunized women just require a booster Td if the current pregnancy occurred within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

The guidelines recommend replacing TT with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women and isolated tetanus toxoid is no longer recommended.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with knee pain in the right knee. The inspection of the knee is shown below. The range of movements is painful and restricted along with a crepitus that is felt during movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with knee pain and unilateral knee swelling is most likely having osteoarthritis.

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Hip and knee joints
  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

On examination, there is tenderness in the joint. A crepitus is felt on joint movement and the range of movements is painfully restricted. Bouchard's and Heberden's nodes may be palpated in PIP and DIP respectively.

Characteristic features of osteoarthritis seen on plain X-ray are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

The image below is an X-ray of osteoarthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. Its onset is around the age of 45-50 years. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that relieves with activity. It typically starts in small peripheral joints[metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints], is usually symmetric, and progresses to involve proximal joints if left untreated. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger.

Option C: Gout is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Clinical features include painful, stiff or swollen joint, deformity of the affected joint (most commonly first metatarsophalangeal joint), and subcutaneous nodules.

The radiograph is normal in the initial stages while it shows erosions, punched-out lesions, and sclerosis with preservation of joint space in the late stages. 

Option D: Pseudogout results from the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate in the joints. It can be associated with hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypophosphatasia, and hypomagnesemia. It presents features similar to acute gout.

Synovial fluid analysis under polarized light shows

  • Negatively birefringent needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals in gout
  • Positive birefringent rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout. 

This patient's age and history are more suggestive of osteoarthritis. The knee joint is the most commonly affected in pseudogout but in this age group, osteoarthritis is a more common disease compared to pseudogout.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the history of no previous illness is most likely of primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon:

  • Episodic digital ischemia due to the vasospasm of digital arteries.
  • Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger it.
  • The blanching/ischemic phase of the phenomenon with pallor/cyanosis is often accompanied by numbness and paraesthesia.
  • Capillaries and venules dilate and cyanosis results from the deoxygenated blood that is present in these vessels.
  • Color changes are usually well-demarcated and are confined to the fingers or toes.
  • In the rewarming phase, digital vasospasm resolves and blood flows into the dilated arterioles and capillaries increase dramatically causing reactive hyperemia which imparts bright red color to the digits.
  • Some may experience only pallor cyanosis while others experience both pallor and cyanosis.

Types of Raynaud's:
     1.Primary/idiopathic 

     2. Secondary associated with other diseases like: 

  • Collagen vascular diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • Arterial occlusive diseases: atherosclerosis of the extremities, thromboangiitis
    obliterans, acute arterial occlusion
  • Neurologic disorders: intervertebral disk disease, syringomyelia
  • Blood dyscrasias: cold agglutinins, cryoglobulinemia, cryofibrinogenemia,
  • Trauma: vibration injury, electric shock, cold injury, typing, piano playing
  • Drugs and toxins: ergot derivatives, methysergide, β-adrenergic receptor
    blockers

Management:

  • Reassurance, warm clothing, and avoiding cold exposures.
    exposure.
  • Reduce or abstain from smoking and reduce stress levels.
  • Drug treatments such as CCB's(nifedipine, amlodipine), alpha 1 blockers ( prazosin) are used only for advanced cases.
  • In secondary Raynauds's Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors like sildenafil, tadalafil may improve symptoms.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood stained stools. The barium enema study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological image of the claw sign/pincer sign in barium enema is suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign -also known as the doughnut sign
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles the renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Other options:

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea and/or vomiting. It shows a coffee bean sign.

 

Option C: Barium enema radiograph in colonic diverticulitis shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

 

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes lead pipe appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding UTI in pregnancy?

choices.text: It is lower in people with sickle cell trait
The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin
If ASB is not treated 75 % of them will develop symptomatic infection

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding UTI in pregnancy is that the preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin.

Asymptomatic bacteriuria(ASB) is characterized by persistent and actively multiplying bacteria in the urinary tract without any symptoms. It is defined as the presence of ≥105 colony-forming units/mL in a urine culture. Its prevalence during pregnancy is around 2-7% and it is a precursor of infection.

It is more common in patients with sickle cell anaemia/trait and diabetes. There is a high risk of developing chronic renal lesions in later life. ASB in pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of premature labour and low birth weight.

If ASB is not treated approximately 25% of the affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy

The oral antibiotics that can be used to treat asymptomatic bacteriuria are amoxicillin, ampicillin, cephalosporin, nitrofurantoin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg, pulses were feeble. JVP was found to be elevated with an absent 'y descent', and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with Beck's triad including hypotension, muffled heart sounds and elevated JVP suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. 

Symptoms of cardiac tamponade include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue. Examination findings are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration
  • Beck's triad: Distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds and hypotension.

An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow. ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction.

Management of cardiac tamponade:

  • Emergency management - ultrasound-guided needle pericardiocentesis via subxiphoid route 
  • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD who reports aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his relatives over the past 7 months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has had auditory hallucinations for the past 7 months, which makes the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely of the given options.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1-month overt psychotic symptoms where 2 or more of the following have to be present. And at least one must be delusion, hallucination or disorganised speech.

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

A mood disorder & substance abuse should be excluded first.

This person has come to seek medical care for hearing voices of aliens (not thoughts or beliefs)which is telling him to kill his relatives, causing impairment. These are consistent with schizophrenia.

Other options:

Option A: Mania: Mania is a key feature of bipolar disorder, characterized by an elevated mood, increased energy levels, and racing thoughts. Persistent auditory hallucinations commanding the individual to harm others is not typically seen in mania alone. Additionally, the duration of 7 months suggests a more chronic and enduring condition, which is not consistent with a typical manic episode.

Option B: Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more persistent delusions without the significant impairment of other cognitive functions or the presence of hallucinations. 

Option D: Brief psychotic disorder: Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, or behavior, that last for less than one month. 

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: Which among the following deficiency is a common cause of cognitive impairment in old age?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to cognitive impairment especially in old age as intake of food is less and nutritional deficiency occurs.

Vit B12 deficiency is a common cause of reversible dementia and can even lead to apathy, depressed mood, confusion, and memory deficits. These are manifested at concentrations less than 150mg/dl and treatment is by administration of Vit B12.

Causes of dementia are:

Reversible 

  • Intracranial tumors
  • Subdural hematoma
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency, niacin deficiency
  • Meningitis (tubercular, fungal, malignant)

Irreversible 

  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lewy body disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
  • Pick's disease

Other options:

A) Vitamin C: While vitamin C is important for overall health, cognitive impairment in old age is not commonly associated with vitamin C deficiency.

C) Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms, but severe cognitive impairment in old age is not typically associated with it.

D) Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 deficiency is often associated with chronic alcoholism rather than being a common cause of cognitive impairment in old age

questions.text: Which disease is associated with the characteristic 'hair on end' appearance of the skull?
questions.solution:
The appearance of "hair on end" on a skull is typically associated with hemolytic anemias like sickle cell anemia and thalassemias.

The hair on end sign refers to a radiographic appearance in which trabeculae are perpendicular in orientation, interspersed by radiolucent marrow hyperplasia along the skull vault. 

It is present in:

  • sickle cell disease
  • thalassemia major
  • hereditary spherocytosis
  • iron deficiency anemia
  • neuroblastoma
  • G-6-PD deficiency

Other options:

Multiple myeloma: 'punched out' lesions in skull

 

Langerhans histicytosis:solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.

Pagets disease:‘Cotton wool skull’

questions.text: The ultrasound finding of a 24-year-old primi with 3 months of amenorrhoea is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterised by partial degenerative or partial proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has some malignant potential and hence requires follow-up.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appears as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has fewer hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented previous history of chlamydia infection now presents with low-grade fever and non-specific lower abdominal pain. Examination reveals mild diffuse lower abdominal tenderness on deep palpation, cervical motion tenderness, and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge. What is the long-term sequelae of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a pelvic inflammatory disease and the most important complication of it is infertility.

Pelvic Inflammatory disease involves inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries. The most common cause of PID in sexually active young females is sexually transmitted infections involving gonococci and chlamydia.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses (hydrosalpinx or pyosalpinx), chronic interstitial salpingitis, tubo ovarian cyst and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with abnormal liver function tests.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

Criteria to diagnose PID:

Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness.

Additional criteria

  • Oral temperature >38.3 oC
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Presence of abundant WBC on saline microscopy of vaginal fluid
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or C.trachomatis.

The definitive diagnosis of PID is through:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy.
  • Imaging (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes i.e., tubo-ovarian abscess.
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID.

Treatment

  • OPD management of PID:
    • Inj.Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg BD x 14 days.
  • Parenteral treatment for PID (in hospitalised:
    • Inj Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100 mg BD or
    • Inj Cefoxitin 2g IV QID + Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and partners have been adequately treated.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. He has a known history of Crohn's disease . Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. On imaging Ileal Perforation is diagnosed. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with Ileal perforation and physical examination findings of rigidity and guarding suggests peritonitis due to perforation. The next best step in the management of this patient is urgent surgical exploration with an ileostomy.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. Common causes include iatrogenic (surgery, scopes) blunt or penetrating injury, bowel obstruction, peptic ulcer disease, corrosive agents, or particular medications.

This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management - Initial management includes intravenous (IV) fluid therapy, cessation of oral intake, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Indications for immediate bowel exploration are

  1. Sepsis/diffuse peritonitis(as in this patient)
  2. Bowel ischemia
  3. Complete or closed-loop bowel obstruction

Resection or repair of the perforated site with or without drainage and diversion is usually undertaken. Duodenal perforations, on the other hand, are generally treated with omental patch repair without resection.

questions.text: Following appearance in IVP is caused by ______
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign in the given IVP depicts cobra head/ adder head deformity seen in bilateral ureterocele.

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1mg/dl, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 25-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome: similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver
