questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with post-coital bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the following lesion is seen which bleeds on touching. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image with the history of post-coital bleeding in a woman of childbearing age is suggestive of a cervical polyp.

Endocervical polyp:

  • They arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal and form a swelling about the size of a pea.
  • The mucous polypi are regarded as being produced by hyperplasia of the mucous membrane of the cervical canal which becomes thrown into folds and finally one of the folds, which projects into the cervical canal, assumes the characteristics of a polypus.
  • The lesion is red and vascular which bleeds easily on the touch and is covered by smooth glistening epithelium with clear mucus.
  • The polypus is pedunculated, the pedicle being attached to the mucous membrane of the cervical canal.
  • Histologically, the surface epithelium is the high columnar type similar to that of the endocervical canal. Glands found in the stroma are lined by tall columnar epithelium. The stroma is extremely vascular, containing a large number of dilated capillaries with round-celled infiltration near the lower pole of the polypus.
  • Occur in women during the childbearing period of life, but may occasionally develop in menopausal and postmenopausal women.
    Treatment- avulsion or by torsion and specimen should always be sent for microscopic examination as malignant changes may be seen.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of palpitations, headache, and sweating. Her blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg, heart rate is 135/min. CT abdomen shows a suprarenal mass. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. Her mother had h/o renal cell carcinoma. What is the most likely syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pheochromocytoma along with the h/o renal cell carcinoma is suggestive of Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.

The main clinical feature of pheochromocytoma is hypertension. Most patients have paroxysmal episodes, which are abrupt elevations in blood pressure. They are accompanied by tachycardia, palpitations, headache, and sweating. Lab diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is based on the demonstration of increased urinary excretion of free catecholamines and their metabolites such as VMA

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease:

  • It is an inherited, autosomal dominant syndrome(chromosome 3).
  • It is manifested by a variety of benign and malignant tumours which include hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinomas (RCCs), and pheochromocytomas.

Familial syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma

MEN IIA ENDEMIC AFRICAN Sturge weber syndrome Von Hippel Linda syndrome Von Recklinghausen syndrome
  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia
  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Mucosal neuroma
  • Marfanoid featured
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Cavernous hemangioma of Vth cranial nerve distribution
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
  • Angiomatosis
  • Renal hepatic pancreatic & epididymal cyst 
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Cafe au late spots
  • Schwannoma,glioma,meningiomas

questions.text: A child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV- 70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low Hb, low MCV, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear is suggestive of thalassemia and Hb electrophoresis should be done in this for diagnosis.

Hb Electrophoresis is used for newborn screening. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the investigation of choice but is not as definitive as globin gene sequencing. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

Haemoglobin levels:

  • Normal hemoglobin pattern- HbA=95%, HbA2=3.5%, HbF =1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia trait- HbA=90%, HbA2=5%, HbF=5%
  • Beta-thalassemia intermedia- HbA=45%, HbA2=5%, HbF=50%

Clinical features in thalassemia:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Iron overload
  • Growth impairment
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Laboratory studies:

  • Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anaemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. These findings are non-specific. 
  • High RBC count 
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • High LDH, high indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, and negative Coomb's test
  • High transferrin saturation, normal serum iron levels, elevated ferritin levels

Other options:

Option A: Measurement of serum iron is necessary to monitor for iron overload in case of repeated blood transfusion. But in this case, the first step is to confirm the diagnosis by doing Hb electrophoresis.

Option B: Direct Coomb's test is used to test for AIHA- Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia. Given the history, AIHA seems unlikely and it usually occurs in adults and is unusual in a child.

Option C: Osmotic fragility test is a test done in the case of hereditary spherocytosis. It presents with splenomegaly, anemia, and hyperbilirubinemia. The MCV is decreased and MCHC is increased due to dehydration. It is unlikely to have a history of chronic blood transfusion.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

The table below describes the features of typical thalassemia syndromes:

"-" denotes deletion of an alpha gene and "α" denotes normal alpha gene and "α* " refers to a mutant alpha chain gene.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty following a road accident. The patient is unconscious; the following image shows the CT scan. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concave-convex shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of subdural hematoma.

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses. The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands. Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy. On CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Chronic subdural hematoma results from a hematoma that expands over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits. On a CT scan, diffuse hypodensity overlying the brain surface would be seen as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. What is the appropriate dosage of Misoprostol administered by the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
The dosage of Misoprostol administered by mucosal route in this case, is 800 mcg.

Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal.

Medical management protocol for induced abortion for < 12 weeks of gestation (As per WHO 2018 guideline):

  • Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9 weeks)

Various regimens for medical termination of pregnancy

First trimester

  • Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended)
  • Misoprostol-only regimen (Alternative)

Second Trimester

  • Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours
  • Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours
  • Dinoprostone- 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr
  • Concentrated Oxytocin- 50 units of oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused in an incremental fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units of oxytocin each in 500 mL of normal saline

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?
questions.solution:
Creating tobacco control laws is a method of primary prevention.

Making tobacco control laws targets smokers who are already exposed to risk of smoking, who have not yet developed any disease. This aims to reduce smoking which is essentially a reduction of risk factor which is a primary prevention stratergy.

Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, whose aim is to prevent the disease from occuring. Its target population is healthy individuals. It commonly institutes activities that limit risk exposure or increase the immunity of individuals at risk to prevent a disease from progressing in a susceptible individual. They approaches can be as follows:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text: A primigravida presents with labour pain and on per vaginal examination her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced.What stage of labour is she in?
questions.solution:
This woman in the active stage of labour with 7 cm cervical dilation is in the phase of maximum slope. 

The first stage of labour can be divided into the latent phase and the active phase based on cervical dilatation. Only for the purpose of partograph and the division that was given by Friedman, we divide the first stage of labour as below.

The latent phase of labour is defined as the period between the onset of true labour pain and the point when the cervical dilatation becomes 3–4 cm. The normal duration of the latent phase of labour in a primigravida is about 20 hours (average 8.6 hours) and 14 hours (average 5.3 hours) in a multipara.

The active phase has got three components:

  1. Acceleration phase with cervical dilatation of 3–4 cm.
  2. The phase of maximum slope of 4–9 cm dilatation.
  3. The phase of deceleration of 9–10 cm dilatation.

According to ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)

  • Latent phase- From the onset of true labour pain up to 6 cm cervical dilatation
  • Active phase - Starts from ≥ 6 cm cervical dilatation.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with the following deformity. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of a child with abnormally approximated knees, divergent ankles, and increased intermalleolar distances depicts genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees of physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase in angle can result in Genu valgum or knock knee where knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.

Intermalleolar distance has been used to assess the degree of genu valgum. It is the distance between the medial malleoli in a standing patient with touching medial femoral condyles. Intermalleolar distances greater than 8 cm are considered pathologic.

Children start developing physiologic genu valgum by age 2, and it becomes most prominent between ages 3 to 4. After that, it typically decreases to a stable, slightly valgus position by age 7 years. Other causes include

  • Bilateral Genu Valgum: Physiologic genu valgum, skeletal dysplasia, metabolic bone diseases, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Unilateral Genu Valgum: Trauma, tumors, and infection.
Osteoarthritis of the knee Rheumatoid arthritis of the knee
Genu varum more common Genu valgum more common
Subchondral sclerosis  Periarticular osteopenia 
No soft tissue swelling  Soft tissue swelling (pannus)
Osteophytes No osteophytes 
Hard and bony joint Soft, warm, and tender joint
Rheumatoid factor negative Rheumatoid factor positive

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backward bending.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a lump in her left breast. Examination reveals a 6 X 4 cm mass in her left breast and a single mobile lymph node palpable under the mass. Which of the following is the best-recommended surgical treatment modality in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical mastectomy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma of the breast. This patient has breast cancer at T3N1M0 disease which belongs to stage III A. The preferred treatment of choice in such patients is modified radical mastectomy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

Pre-operative chemotherapy and postoperative radiotherapy will add to the benefit of the patients. Considerations for treatment of Stage III A and III B disease are summarized in the flowchart as shown below. 

The treatment of breast cancer should be individualized and based on various clinical factors. However, a general idea of it is as follows.

When systemic adjuvant therapy is given before the surgery it is called neoadjuvant therapy.

Early-stage localised cancer(stages 0, I , II) can be treated by mastectomy or breast-conserving therapy(BCT). BCT requires radiation to further improve patient benefit. 

Locally advanced breast cancer(stages IIIA, IIIB) breast adenocarcinoma without distant metastases. It includes breast cancer that fulfils any of the following criteria in the absence of distant metastasis (M0):

  • Tumours more than 5 cm in size with regional lymphadenopathy: T3, N1-3
  • Tumours of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, or both (including ulcer, oedema or satellite nodules): Any T4
  • Presence of clinically fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes, or any infraclavicular, supraclavicular, or internal mammary lymphadenopathy: Any N2 or Any N3

LABC is treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy + modified radical mastectomy + adjuvant radiation therapy. If ER/PR receptor positivity is present then hormonal therapy is added, and if Her-2/neu receptor positivity is present, then Trastuzumab / Herceptin is added.

Metastatic cancer(stage IV) Treatment of metastatic cancer is aimed at palliating symptoms, improving quality of life, preventing potential disabling complications and attempting to prolong life.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: Identify the deformity depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This deformity is known as Boutonnière deformity seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 Rheumatoid Arthritis :

It is a chronic inflammatory disease. Its incidence increases between 25 and 55 years of age.

Signs and symptoms -

  • Swelling and pain of the small joints of the hands initially(spares DIP joint)
  • Morning stiffness
  • Swan-neck deformity(hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint), Boutonnière deformity(flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint), or Z-line deformity(subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint )
  • Ulnar deviation of fingers
  • Constitutional findings such as fever, weight loss, etc
  • Monoarthritis of large joints can occur later
  • Tenosynovitis of palm(trigger finger0
  • Atlantoaxial joint involvement

Joints commonly affected in Rheumatoid Arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involved) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

Diagnosis is made with clinical signs and symptoms with corroboration from lab and imaging findings.

Anti-CCP, RF, and synovial fluid analysis are important lab investigations.

X-ray findings show -
soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and bony erosions

Treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) are the mainstay of treatment.

Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

  • It is a folic acid analong
  • Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • Causes reversible myelosuppression
  • Leucovorin is used to manage myelosuppression
  • Can cause pulmonary fibrosis
  • Escalation with triple therapy involves - methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine
  • Glucocorticoids 

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, Mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, Interstitial Lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

The image below shows extraarticular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis -

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child is brought to the OPD with cramping abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rashes on the back of her legs, buttocks and the extensor surface of her forearms. Laboratory analysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this child with rash, abdominal pain and nephritis is Henoch-Schönlein purpura.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterized by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis

Children usually present with the following features:

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks.
  • Arthralgia and arthritis- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, and intussusception.
  • About 30% of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, presenting as microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal. 

Most clinical features of IgA vasculitis are self-limiting and resolve in a few days. Supportive management with the maintenance of hydration and pain relief is done. Patients developing nephritis due to IgA vasculitis may need aggressive management with immunosuppressants.

The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP.

questions.text: GCS of a patient who had a road-traffic accident is 10. Using the GCS scoring system, the head injury of this patient is classified as:
questions.solution:
Using the Glasgow Coma Scale score(GCS) , the head injury of this patient with a GCS 10 is classified as moderate.

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. The maximum GCS score is 15 (E4 V5 M6).

Based on the GCS score, the head injury sustained can be classified as follows:

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • ≤8 represent severe injury 

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument?
questions.solution:
This is the image of the laryngeal mask airway (LMA).

It aids in intubation in case of difficult airway.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Position:

  • Distal tip lies against the Upper esophageal sphincter.
  • Proximal tip juxtaposed with base of the tongue.
  • Side cuffs cover pyriform fossa.

Contraindications:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Pharyngeal obstruction
  • Restrictive airway disease
  • Hiatal hernia
  • Pregnancy

Option a:

Guedel airway -

It is an oral airway which is used to create and maintain air passage between tongue and posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option c:

Endotracheal tube -

Endotracheal intubation is usually performed emergency procedure to secure airway where endotracheal tube is placed in the trachea by passing it through mouth or nose.

Option d:

Nasogastric tube –

It is passed into the stomach via nose. It has many diagnostic and therapeutic uses like aspiration of stomach contents, evaluation of upper GI bleed, stomach wash in case of poisoning etc.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.
  • Mouth opening < 1.5cm

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 20 cm of H2O.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, presenting with 12 weeks of amenorrhea, underwent a sonographic evaluation that revealed a twin gestation, as shown in the image below. What type of twins are depicted in this ultrasound?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in Dichorionic Diamniotic(DCDA) twin pregnancy.

If the inner cell mass divides within 3 days, it leads to the formation of dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twins. The sonographic image of DCDA is given below.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs. A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign. The presence of lambda or twin peak sign indicates a dichorionic placenta.

Twinning and time of division:

Time of division Type of twin
<3 days  Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) 
4-8 days Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
>8 days Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days  Conjoint twins

 

Other options :

Option a : In monochorionic diamniotic gestation, the twins are separated only by the two amniotic membranes, with no intervening chorion. So, a thin 'T sign' is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. It is best seen in the latter part of the first trimester or at the beginning of the second trimester. 

Option c : In monochorionic monoamniotic gestation, there is an absence of a dividing membrane.

Option d :  Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

 

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

Other options:

Option A: Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females

Option C: Psoriasis:

  • The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are red, and scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis:

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. 
  • It typically appears in the 4th decade,  most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp.
  • On examination, multiple erythematous papules and vesicles can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

questions.text: A mother complains that her child is reluctant when it comes to taking feeds appropriately. Her 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median is having moderate stunting.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also called as wasting as a result of a recent food deficit or an acute illness such as diarrhea.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight for age, or underweight indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children. Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age) is given in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: Which of the following tests would a surgeon advise first in a  patient with a large thyroid swelling?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first investigation done in any thyroid condition.

Evaluation of any thyroid disease should begin with the assessment of TSH, T3, and T4. TSH is the only test necessary in most patients with thyroid nodules that clinically appear to be euthyroid. 

If a discrete swelling is associated with hyperthyroidism, it indicates a toxic adenoma. This is followed by an ultrasound of the neck or radioiodine uptake. Findings in thyroid swelling associated with thyroid neoplasia include microcalcification and increased vascularity. FNAC should be used under ultrasound guidance, on all nodules that fall outside a fully benign category.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include:

  • Laboratory evaluation
    • TSH
    • T3
    • T4 
  • Thyroid imaging
    • Ultrasound
    • Radioisotope scanning
    • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
    • Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)
    • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis &  WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (Thrush) is categorized as WHO clinical stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with immunosupression and Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema
  • Herpes zoster
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Stage 3

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Lymph node TB
  • Pulmonary TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Stage 4

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)
  • Chronic Herpes Simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi Sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her pediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient, normal physical findings except for a systolic murmur, and wide and fixed (does not vary with respiration) splitting of S2 are all in favor of a diagnosis of Atrial septal defect.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve. Since the two atria are linked, inspiration does not produce any net pressure changes between them abolishing respiration-related changes in venous return hence causing fixed S2. 

Other options:

Option A: TAPVC patients usually present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure around 4-10 weeks of age. This is when the fetal pulmonary vasculature regresses and there is increased pulmonary blood flow which results in early-onset cardiac failure. The physical findings are identical to ASD.

Option B: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Pulmonic stenosis is an acyanotic heart disease and physical findings include an ejection systolic murmur and a thrill in the left second intercostal space and a wide and variable split S2 because of delayed closure of P2.

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is?

choices.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is Karman’s cannula which is used for menstrual regulation or aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote , and an ectopic pregnancy can be missed.

Other options:

Option A:  Hysterosalpingography is done using a Rubins cannula.

 

Option B:  The length of the uterus is measured using Simpson's uterine sound.

Option C: Retraction is done using Doyen's retractor

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 72-year-old retired pilot presents to a neurologist, accompanied by his wife, with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus ,ataxia, and  visual disturbances. FLAIR MRI scans is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia and visual disturbances along with the FLAIR MRI which shows hockey stick sign, is diagnostic of variant CJD.

The hockey stick sign refers to the hyper-intense signal involving the pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclei bilaterally on FLAIR or DWI. This sign is commonly indicative of variant (infectious acquired) CJD. Whereas MRI in sporadic CJD reveals abnormalities in the cortical grey matter called cortical ribboning.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a spongiform encephalopathy that is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual disturbances. It is fatal and death usually within a year or less from the onset.

The proteins that make up the prions (PrP) are present even normally in the cells. This normal form, PrPc, is in a predominantly α-helical configuration and is sensitive to proteases. However, the prions (infectious form) are in an abnormal β-pleated configuration and are called PrPSc. This pathological form is not degradable by proteases and converts the normal form- PrPc to the abnormal form- PrPSc. This abnormal protein gets deposited as plaques and degeneration of surrounding neuronal and glial tissue occurs characterized by intracellular vacuoles, leading to a characteristic spongiform encephalopathy. There is no associated inflammatory response to these agents. 

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  • Sporadic (sCJD): Most common;
  • Variant (vCJD): Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), Kuru;
  • Familial (fCJD): These individuals carry a PrPc mutation and include Gerstmann-Sträussler- Scheinker syndrome and fatal familial insomnia;
  • Iatrogenic (iCJD): Maybe seen occurring after corneal transplantation, liver transplantation, use of contaminated neurosurgical instruments, use of cadaver-derived hormones, or stereotactic depth electrodes. 

Clinically, CJD presents with predominantly CNS manifestations with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus (startle myoclonus is common), ataxia, akinetic mutism, visual disturbances, and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction. Insomnia, apathy, and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen. 

CSF is predominantly normal but may show a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. MRI on FLAIR sequencing and diffusion-weighted imaging will show increased intensity in the basal ganglia region and a characteristic 'cortical ribboning', in sporadic CJD. Diagnosis of CJD can be established on brain biopsy either by measuring PrPSc or by demonstrating the characteristic neuropathological features of spongiform encephalopathy. EEG may show periodic triphasic or multiphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes or spike-wave pattern.

Management is mainly supportive as the disease is usually fatal within a year of onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient had a road traffic accident and is now bleeding profusely. He is hypotensive and needs large volume replacement with IV fluids. What cannula gauge will you use in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, since large volume replacement is needed and is hypotensive, a 14 gauge cannula has to be used which delivers fluids at a rate of 270 ml/min.

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker's oral examination. Identify the lesion given.
questions.solution:
The given image with a white lesion of the tongue in a smoker is suggestive of oral leukoplakia

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. It is seen anywhere in the upper aerodigestive tract. It may represent squamous hyperplasia, dysplasia, and/or carcinoma with an associated risk of malignant transformation

It is defined as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. Risk factors include tobacco (including cigars, cigarettes, beedi, and pipes), alcohol consumption and chronic irritation.

A biopsy should be done to establish a diagnosis and an appropriate work-up is done if carcinoma is identified. Cessation of smoking, elimination of the areca nut/pan habit, and reduction in alcohol consumption should be encouraged. For lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia, surgical excision or laser surgery should be the treatment of choice.

Oral hairy leukoplakia is a different entity caused by the Epstein-Barr virus(EBV). It is due to the reactivation of EBV occurring in association with immunodeficiency commonly from HIV infection. It presents as white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 

Other white lesions of oral mucosa:

  • Lichen planus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus
  • White spongy nevus
  • Candidiasis

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal breast and pubic hair development, but her vagina ends in a blind pouch, and her uterus is not palpable. What is the next step in the investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and non-palpable uterus, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. The next step would be to do an ultrasound to look for uterine anomalies.

Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. In this condition, the ovaries are normal and secondary sexual characters are well-developed with normal external genitalia. This condition is associated with anomalies of the spine/skeleton and the kidneys along with the urinary tract.

Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography, MRI or laparoscopy. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity. These should be surgically excised if they are symptomatic.

Given below is an algorithm for the diagnosis of primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characteristics:

questions.text: Which of the following MRI imaging techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows CSF as bright/hyperintense while white matter is dark and grey matter is white, hence this is a T2 weighted MRI image. 

T1 weighted image

  • It is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences.
  • The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times.
  • CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark.

T2 weighted images:

  • It is also a basic MRI pulse sequence.
  • It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues.
  • CSF appears bright in these images.

 

Short tau inversion recovery(STIR):

  • It is a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fat.
  • The imaging sequence is identified by observing the fat tissues and fluid-filled spaces.
  • Fluids like CSF appear bright and fat appears dark.

 

Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR):

  • It is also a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fluids.
  • Fluids like CSF appear dark and pathological processes appear bright.
  • It would appear as a fluid suppressed T2 image.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after spilling hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple blisters are present on his right hand. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and capillary refilling is normal.  Which layers of skin are involved in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and normal capillary refilling time has second-degree superficial burns. The layers of skin involved here are the epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis).

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

questions.text: This instrument is not used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image is a proctoscope and proctoscopy is contraindicated in acute anal fissures.

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in acute anal fissures. Acute anal fissures are examined under anaesthesia in operating room when needed. 

Anal fissure:

Clinical features

  • Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation
  • It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood noticed on tissue after wiping
  • Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline. Fissures located laterally can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, TB, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of Anal fissure

  • The focus is to normalise bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibres, and adequate water should be recommended
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle.

questions.text:
A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

RIG- Rabies immunoglobulin

choices.text: Wound cleaning+ rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.solution:
This patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

In India, monkeys are known to transmit rabies. Hence the national rabies control program advises a full course of PEP for monkey bites. This patient who was bitten by a monkey 6 months back would have received PEP for rabies. 

Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:

  • Category I: Wound treatment only
  • Category II/ III:
    • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic
    • Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not given for any category in case they have completed a full course of PEP.

*Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play a significant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of two intramuscular (IM) or two intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0 and 3.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in a post-menopausal woman on hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
questions.solution:
Adding progesterone to estrogen in HRT can reduce the risk of potential endometrial cancer.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of oestrogen therapy. For women without a uterus, just estrogen therapy is sufficient. 

Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms,genitourinary syndrome of menopause like vaginal and vulvar atrophy and for the prevention of osteoporosis.

The daily estrogen content in most oral contraceptive pills is 35µg or less and levonorgestrel is 100-150 mg. But the HRT commonly used have a different concentration of estrogen and progesterone. Hence the regular combined oral contraceptive pills are not used.

Clonidine reduces hot flashes during menopause but does not have any action on endometrium. Vitamin E has no role in endometriual proliferation.

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency in a comatose state. Examination reveals serum glucose levels of 500 mg/dL, arterial pH of 7.33, elevated plasma ketones, and normal serum potassium levels. What should be added to the saline in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The patient needs to be started on IV fluids and insulin at a dose of 0.1 unit per kg. 

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Management of DKA

  • Admit to hospital assess for serum electrolytes and acid-base status
  • Replace fluids- 2-3 liters (10-20 mL/kg/hr) of normal saline should be administered over 1-3 hours. Subsequently 0.45% saline at 250-500 mL/hr. It can be changed to 5% glucose and 0.45% saline at 150–250 mL/h when plasma glucose reaches 250 mg/dL.
  • Administer IV short-acting insulin regular insulin. 0.1 units/kg of insulin should be administered immediately as a bolus dose. This is followed by an intravenous infusion of 0.1 units/kg. Serum potassium levels should be checked before initiating insulin. If the levels are high, then it has to be corrected and then insulin should be started.
  • The above measures should be continued until the serum glucose levels reach 150–200 mg/dL, and acidosis is resolved. Insulin infusion may be decreased to 0.02–0.1 units/kg per hour.
  • Long-acting insulin can be started when the patient starts eating.

The chart shows the management algorithm for DKA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The drug of choice in this patient is cefotaxime.

SBP is characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of chronic diarrhea, fatigue, and tiredness. On examination, his nail findings are shown below. Lab investigations show Hb as 8 gm%. Which of the following is the best treatment approach for this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient has chronic diarrhea there is malabsorption of nutrients in this patient. He has anemia from his lab investigations and his nail findings suggest koilonychia(spooning of nails) which is a characteristic finding in iron deficiency anemia. Thus the preferred treatment for this patient is iron supplements.

Malabsorption syndrome refers to a spectrum of conditions of various etiologies that arises due to diminished absorption of one or more dietary nutrients.

Anemia may be present when there is defective absorption of iron, folate, or vitamin B12.

The majority of the patients with iron deficiency anemia present with easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and dyspnea on exertion. Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes like

  • smooth tongue
  • brittle nails
  • koilonychia- spooning of nails
  • cheilosis- fissures at the corner of the mouth
  • pica- craving for specific foods that are not rich in iron.

Laboratory investigation of iron deficiency anemia

The peripheral smear will show small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) cells with an increased area of central pallor. Pencil-shaped cells can be seen which is called poikilocytosis.

Serum iron levels- It represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The normal range for the serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL. It is decreased in iron deficiency anemia.

Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)- It is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal levels are 300–360 μg/dL. The levels are increased in IDA.

Transferrin saturation- The normal levels are 25–50%. The levels are decreased in IDA.

Serum ferritin- Free iron is toxic to the body. Therefore it is bound to a protein called apoferritin to form ferritin. Adult males have serum ferritin values averaging 100 μg/L, while adult females have levels averaging 30 μg/L. The serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. It is decreased in IDA.

Evaluation of bone marrow iron stores- can be done by performing bone marrow biopsy and using the Prussian stain to stain the iron stores. It is rarely done these days due to the availability of the serum ferritin estimation tests.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions
