questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the given image showing abnormal dilation and enlargement of the scrotal venous pampiniform plexus,  like bag of worms is suggestive of a varicocele.

Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. Left-sided varicocele is more common. Most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the testicular vein by a renal tumour or nephrectomy is seen in some cases.

The pathogenesis behind varicocele is due to increased blood flow to the testis leading to higher intratesticular temperatures, which inhibits spermatogenesis and results in low sperm count, motility and morphology. Most varicoceles are asymptomatic. Those symptomatic tend to present in adolescence or early adulthood, with a dragging discomfort that is worse on standing at the end of the day. There may be a cough impulse. Additionally, patients may have infertility.

Grades of varicocele
Grade 1 Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 2 Varicocele palpable without Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 3 Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment. Treatment of symptomatic and young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:

  • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method )
  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) 
  • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route

In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate. 

Other options : 

Option a: Hydrocele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. In the case of a primary hydrocoele, as the fluid is collected within a closed sac, a cough impulse is unlikely to be seen. Important positive clinical findings in a hydrocoele are that they are irreducible,  the testes cannot be palpated separately, ability to get above the swelling, and transillumination of the swelling.

Option c : Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous.

Option d : Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and is associated with the degeneration of striatal neurons. Features such as chorea and dementia are commonly seen in these patients. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioral changes.

Option C: ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

questions.text: Interpret the finding of the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a regular rhythm, narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent P waves is suggestive of supraventricular tachycardia. 

Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles

  • Tachycardias originating from the atrium:
    • Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node
    • Focal atrial tachycardia
    • Multifocal atrial tachycardia
    • Atrial flutter 
    • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tachycardias originating from the AV node:
    • Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node
    • AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT)
  • Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia(AVRT).

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is given below.

ECG in Atrial fibrillation also shows absent p waves, narrow QRS complex, and irregularly irregular RR interval with a heart rate ranging between 110-160 beats/minute

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

questions.text: An old person presented with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly and rolled margins. Histopathology shows nesting cells with peripheral palisading patterns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, presenting with an ulcer on the medial canthus with pearly, rolled margins, and histopathology revealing nesting cells with peripheral palisading, is most likely diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing, locally invasive, malignant tumour of epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis. It erodes deeply into local tissues, including cartilage and bones, causing extensive local destruction, hence the name rodent ulcer. It does not spread through blood or lymphatics. 

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face. Most common site is the inner canthus of eye.

They present as small, slowly growing pearly nodules, often with tortuous telangiectatic vessels on their surface, rolled borders, and a central crust (nodular BCC). The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

BCC can be divided into generalized and localized. Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Naevoid.

The characteristic biopsy finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other Options:

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns). Classically, it appears as a scaly or ulcerated papule or plaque that can bleed with minimal trauma, but the pain is rare. Histologically, SCC is characterized by the proliferation of atypical squamous cells with the formation of horn pearls or keratin pearls.

Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. 

The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar. 

Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused by mutations in the RAS signalling pathway, characterized by aggregates of melanocytes at the dermis or the dermo-epidermal junction. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. It can get transformed into malignant melanoma and the features suggestive of malignant transformation are a change in size, shape, color, thickness, satellite lesions, and tingling/ itching/serosanguinous discharge.

questions.text: Which disease is being represented in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given picture describes Cushing's.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion
  • Ectopic ACTH production

Important clinical features:

  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is done only after a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established in a patient.

The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used in patients with confirmed Cushing syndrome. It helps to differentiate between Cushing's disease (i.e a pituitary cause) and ectopic ACTH production.

The basis for this test is that in subjects with Cushing's disease, a higher dose of dexamethasone (usually 8 mg) is required to suppress ACTH secretion and drop cortisol levels in serum, urine, and saliva.

Standard 2-day (high dose) dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Serum cortisol level and/or 24-hour urinary free cortisol is measured as a baseline, and then dexamethasone 2 mg orally is taken every 6 hours for 48 hours; urine for free cortisol is collected during the test and serum cortisol is checked 6 hours after the last dose. The suppression of cortisol secretion to >50 % of the baseline is considered positive and indicative of Cushing's disease

The following four investigations are used to establish an initial diagnosis of endogenous Cushing's syndrome as per the clinical guidelines of the endocrine society.

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (increased 3x above normal)
  • Midnight salivary cortisol ( >5nmol/L)
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression (plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 AM after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 PM)
  • Standard 2-day (low dose) dexamethasone suppression test (plasma cortisol > 50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone 6th hourly for 48 hours).  

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following methods of cervical ripening is a type of hygroscopic dilator?

choices.text: Foley catheter at internal os of cervix

questions.solution:
Among the given methods of cervical ripening, the one which is a type of hygroscopic dilator is an intracervical laminaria tent.

Hygroscopic osmotic dilators are devices that draw water from cervical tissues and expand to gradually dilate the cervix. They expand to an ultimate diameter 3-4 times that of its dry state.

Laminaria tent is derived from various species of Laminaria algae that are harvested from the ocean floor. Synthetic dilators include Dilapan and Lamicel.

The image below shows Dilapan on the left and Laminaria tent on the right:        

Pharmacological methods of cervical ripening:          

Misoprostol at a dose of 25 μg is placed in the posterior fornix. Although it has increased efficacy, it is associated with a higher incidence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) and uterine tachysystole, especially when used in higher doses.         

Dinoprostone is the synthetic analog of PGE2, available in three forms, as a gel, as a time-release vaginal insert, and as a suppository. Of these, the first two forms are used in cervical ripening whereas suppository is used only in abortion 

The gel form is available in a prefilled syringe for local application in the cervical canal. The dosage used per procedure is 0.5 mg. This procedure can be repeated for a maximum of 3 doses in 24 hours with a time interval of 6 hours between each administration. The vaginal insert has a dose of 10 mg of dinoprostone. This releases the drug at a rate of 0.3 mg/hr. It is positioned horizontally in the posterior fornix of the vagina. 

Monitoring uterine contraction and fetal heart rate is a must after each dose. Adverse effects of dinoprostone include uterine tachysystole (especially when the gel is used in labour that has started spontaneously).           

Cervidil (Dinoprostone) vaginal insert:

Note : Dinoprostone which is a synthetic analogue of PGE2, not to be confused with Dinoprost is a natural PGF2-alpha preparation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with low backache and weight loss. He has progressive difficulty in urination and had an episode of urinary retention 2 days back which was relieved by catheterization.PSA was done which was  5.2 ng/ml and an X-Ray LS spine shows osteoblastic changes. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details with elevated PSA and blastic changes in the LS spine suggest a diagnosis of carcinoma prostate.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignant tumour in men over the age of 65 years. The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens.  Approximately 70% of carcinomas of the prostate arise in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location.

Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements. Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination.

Local extension most commonly involves the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the obturator nodes and the para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in decreasing order of frequency. 

Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

Measurement of serum PSA levels is widely used to assist in the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer.  

Prostatic biopsy specimen showing foci of small crowded glands, some showing cribriform pattern of arrangement.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of the Alvarado score for the diagnosis of appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Elevated BP is not a component of the Alvarado score for the diagnosis of appendicitis.

The components of the Alvarado scoring system can be remembered using the mnemonic MANTRELS

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months.  On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of pelvic organ prolapse with a decubitus ulcer. It is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes. 

Friction, congestion and circulatory changes in the dependent part of prolapse cause keratinization and pigmentation of the vaginal mucosa, as well as ulceration of the prolapsed tissue with a clean edge.

Treatment includes the reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine. Acriflavine is an antiseptic agent while glycerine is a hygroscopic agent. This helps in the healing of the ulcer within a week or two.

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of the ureter with resulting renal damage can occur in procidentia and enterocele.
  • Chronic Urinary tract infection due to retention of urine in a cystocele, and can lead to upper renal tract infec­tion and renal damage.
  • Decubitus ulcer due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes.
  • Stress incontinence occurs when the internal urinary meatus and neck of the bladder descend below the level of pelvic floor muscles.
  • Cancer of the vagina can rarely occur over the decubitus ulcer and if the ring pessary is left in over a long period.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient, who is a known case of ovarian cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in an elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis. 

Other classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

Other options:

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with a malar rash as visualized in the image in the image below. It is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis has findings of mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and resorption of distal phalanges of the fingers.

Option D: Cushing's syndrome presents with easy bruisability and multiple purple striae over the abdomen. They may also have rounding, puffiness, fat deposition, and plethora in the face collectively called the moon facies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of intrauterine contraception CuT 380 A which is not contraindicated in HIV-infected women

Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are placed in the uterine cavity with the objective of providing long-term contraception, mainly by preventing fertilisation.

Contraindications for IUCD:

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • STIs — current or recurrent
  • Distorted uterine cavity (fibroids, uterine anomalies)
  • Severe dysmenorrhea
  • Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  • Wilson disease and copper allergy, for copper-containing IUCDs
  • Breast cancer, for hormone-containing IUCDs

Complications of IUCD usage:

    • Immediate 
      • Vasovagal attack
      • Uterine cramps
    • Early 
      • Expulsion of IUCD
      • Perforation of uterus
      • Spotting, menorrhagia 
      • Dysmenorrhoea 
      • Vaginal infection
      • Actinomycosis
    • Late 
      • PID
      • Ectopic pregnancy
      • Perforation of uterus
      • Menorrhagia
      • Dysmenorrhoea

questions.text: A 3-day old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, forceful expulsion of stools on rectal examination, and barium enema showing dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschprung's disease is a rectal biopsy.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

 

They are predominantly seen in boys and are associated with Down syndrome. Most cases present during the neonatal period with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and failure to pass meconium. Later they may also have poor feeding and severe constipation. Forceful expulsion of stools is observed on rectal examination as the stools accumulate in the distal colon.

A barium enema is obtained on all suspected cases. This demonstrates the location of the transition zone between the dilated ganglionic colon and the distal aganglionic rectal segment.  In older children, anorectal manometry shows a high internal sphincter pressure due to the absence of normal inhibitory reflex.

 Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

The definitive surgeries are the Swenson procedure, Duhamel procedure, and Soave's procedure

The most common cause of death in uncorrected Hirschprung's disease is enterocolitis.

questions.text: Whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The whole-body CT of a trauma patient does not include CT limbs.

Whole-body CT or trauma CT or pans can is increasingly being used in the context of trauma patients with a dangerous mechanism of injury:

  1. Non-contrast CT of head
  2. Non-contrast CT of neck
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of chest (arterial phase)
  4. Contrast-enhanced CT of abdomen (portal venous phase)

The purpose of the scan is to rapidly evaluate life-threatening injuries and accurately diagnose known and unknown injuries.

While limb injuries can certainly occur in trauma cases, they are usually assessed through physical examination, X-rays, or targeted CT scans if there is suspicion of a specific injury. Including limb imaging as part of the standard whole-body CT scan protocol would increase the scan time and radiation exposure for the patient without significantly impacting the detection of life-threatening injuries.

Therefore, CT limbs is the exception and is not typically included in the whole-body CT scan protocol for trauma patients.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of weakness on the right side over the last 2 hours. On examination, she had right facial droop, and right hemiplegia and her BP was 180/100 mmHg. Which of the following is the next step of management?

NCCT- Non-contrast CT
questions.solution:
The given features of hemiparesis and facial drooping with aphasia are suggestive of a stroke. The next step of management is NCCT.

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. It can identify extra parenchymal hemorrhages, subarachnoid hemorrhages, neoplasms, abscesses, and other conditions that can mimic stroke. However, in the case of an ischemic stroke, the CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. 

Imaging modalities that can be useful in the early identification of stroke are diffusion-weighted imaging(DWI), fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR), and MR perfusion studies using gadolinium contrast.

Treatment of acute ischemic stroke:

Initial treatment: Check for the patient's pulse rate, blood pressure, temperature, and glucose levels. Treat hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever if present. Maintain the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation.

Blood pressure should be reduced acutely if :

  • Blood pressure > 220/120 mmHg
  • There is malignant hypertension
  • There is concomitant myocardial ischemia
  • Blood pressure is > 185/110 mmHg and the patient is being planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Ischemia can result in edema which peaks on the second or third day and can lead to a mass effect for around 10 days. Therefore, intravenous mannitol should be started and water restriction should be advised for the patients.

Specific measures:

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive within the window period of 4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 325 mg should be started within 24-48 hours of acute ischemic stroke. It is also continued as an adjunct therapy after intravenous thrombolysis.

Routine use of heparin and other oral anticoagulants is not recommended in patients with ischemic stroke because they can increase the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. They can be used if the patient is bedridden, in order to prevent deep vein thrombosis.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetation on either side of the heart valves. What can be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of malar rashes is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus(SLE). The vegetations on both sides of the valves along with SLE and are consistent with Libman Sacks endocarditis.

Sterile/Infective Non-sterile Non-sterile Sterile Sterile

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had a fever, a rash on his hand along with painful sores in his mouth as shown below. What is the causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above clinical condition is hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) caused by coxsackievirus.

It is caused by the coxsackievirus and enterovirus. The serotypes commonly involved are coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus 71. It spreads by droplets or faecal contamination. It can also lead to aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, polio-like syndrome, acute transverse myelitis, and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 

HFMD is characterised by multiple vesicles surrounded by a halo of erythema. These vesicles usually rupture leading to superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base and an erythematous rim. The lesions can be macular, papular, or vesicular. They are generally non-pruritic and non-painful, involving the dorsum of the hand, feet, buttocks, legs, and arms. 

Treatment for HFMD is supportive. Pain and fever can be treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents. The patient should be adequately hydrated.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl suspects that the college principal is making a conspiracy against her and is planning to fail her in the upcoming exam. She feels that other teachers have also joined the conspiracy and students are helping them too. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Thoughts of being harmed by people around themselves represent delusion of persecution. It is the most common type of delusion.

Delusion is a false, firm, fixed (unshakable) belief which is not in keeping with the patient’s socio-cultural and educational background.

Delusions are of two types based on their origin:

  • Primary: Arise de-novo and cannot be explained based on previous experiences, characteristic of schizophrenia.
  • Secondary: Delusions that are secondary to other morbid psychological conditions like depressive moods and hallucinations.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum testing reveals positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The test shown in the image below was positive with a score of < 5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Schirmer's test and the likely diagnosis is Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial (lip) biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis. 

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: Two vacccines - Measles and the pentavalent vaccine are used during an immunisation programme. Which of these vaccines has to be discarded?
questions.solution:
Open vial policy is not applicable for BCG, JE, Measles vaccines and Rota virus.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

Open vial policy  is applicable for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare MMR vaccine history in children with autism and children without autism. What kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a case-control study. Children with autism are cases and without autism are control.

Case-control study is a type of obesrvational study used to test hypothesis. Here the study subjects are divided into cases- those having the disease of interest and controls- those without the disease of interest.  Odds ratio is a measure of strength of the association between risk factor and outcome in these studies.

Other options:

Option A: Cross-sectional study is based on a single examination of a cross-section of population at one point in time and the results can be projected on the whole population.

Option B: Cohort study divides subjects a into those with exposure and without exposure. This study gives relative risk which is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. If this study were to divide children based on those who recieved MMR vaccine and those who did not recieve it to find out any association with autism, it would be called a cohort study.

Option D: A clinical trial is a type of experimental or interventional study. They are manily concerned with evaluating therapeutic agents, mainly drugs.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Odds ratio calculation (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

questions.text: A child with normal IQ and learning skills for his age is weak in mathematics reasoning. Despite being tutored by a private tutor for 1 year, the child showed no improvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis for a child who has normal IQ and learning skills for their age but is weak in mathematical reasoning despite one year of tutoring is a specific learning disorder in mathematics, also known as dyscalculia.

Dyscalculia is a specific learning disorder that affects an individual's ability to understand and work with numbers. It is similar to dyslexia but specifically related to mathematical skills. Children with dyscalculia may have difficulty understanding number concepts, memorizing basic arithmetic facts, and comprehending mathematical symbols and operations.

The learning difficulties begin during school-age years but may not become fully manifest until the demands increase as in a test or exam and are not better accounted for by intellectual disabilities, uncorrected visual or auditory acuity, other mental or neurological disorders, psychosocial adversity, lack of proficiency in the language of academic instruction, or inadequate educational instruction.

The four diagnostic criteria are to be met based on a clinical synthesis of the individual's history (developmental, medical,family, educational), school reports, and psychoeducational assessment.

Note: Dyscalculia is an alternative term used to refer to a pattern of difficulties characterized by problems processing numerical information, learning arithmetic facts, and performing accurate or fluent calculations.

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy once daily for 5 days per week for a duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What is this type of brachytherapy called?
questions.solution:
Since the patient is given a dose of 1.8-2.0 Gy per day for 5 days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, it is called Regular/Conventional Fractionated Radiotherapy.

Radiotherapy:

The total dose of radiation needed for a tumor is usually given as fractions over the entire treatment period as it maximizes the effects of the radiation on the malignant cells and minimizes the damage to the healthy cells.

The reasons for this are due to :

1. Re-distribution: Cells are more resistant to damage in the late S2 phase while sensitive in the M and G2 phase. Only some tumor cells will be in the sensitive phase of the cell cycle when the radiation is given. Hence, giving another dose at a later time helps in killing the other cells that were in the resistant part of the cell cycle, thus increasing the success rate of the therapy.

2. Re-oxygenation: Hypoxic cells are less sensitive to the indirect effects of radiation. The tumor cells which are closer to oxygen sources are killed first and in the intervening time, the other relatively hypoxic cells can improve their oxygenation so that the next fraction of radiation is effective on them. 

3. Repair: The ability to repair DNA is more for healthy cells than malignant cells and thus when a radiation dose has been received, the healthy cells repair their DNA faster than the malignant cells. The malignant cells whose DNA is not fully repaired are highly susceptible to the next dose of radiation.

Types of fractionation:

Standard Fractionation: Radiotherapy(RT) is given once daily for 5 days/week, not more than 2 Gy/fraction.

Accelerated Fractionation:(Option C) Any fractionation schedule that gives >10 Gy/week. Subtypes include:

  • Pure accelerated fractionation (2 Gy/fraction, 6–7 fractions/week)
  • Accelerated hypofractionation (>3 Gy/fraction)
  • Accelerated hyperfractionation (>1 fraction/day)

Hypofractionation: Increased fraction size, with or without a decreased number of fractions/week.

  • Stereotactic Radiation (SRS/SBRT/SABR): RT delivered with stereotactic localization techniques in five fractions or less.
  • Fractionated Stereotactic RT (FSRT): RT delivered with stereotactic techniques and more than five fractions.

Hyperfractionation: Decreased fraction size with more than one fraction per day (BID or TID). (Option B)

Concomitant Boost (CB): Two fractions per day with one fraction to a large field and the other to a boost volume.

Simultaneous Integrated Boost (SIB): One fraction per day with a higher dose to a boost volume and a lower dose to the large field.

Note: Brachytherapy(Option D) is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

questions.text: Following gastrectomy, the patient is most likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
After gastrectomy, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after gastrectomy IF-B12 complex is not formed and there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Folic acid is absorbed mainly in Jejunum.

Gastric ulcer does not occur following gastrectomy.

Constipation is not common after gastrectomy. 

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray image showing the sunburst appearance is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the bone, with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade.

The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis, which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays features include:

  • Codman’s triangle → due to new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation
  • Sunburst appearance → due to new bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor
  • Periosteal reaction → due to the lifting of the periosteum of the bone. Periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumour is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. It usually occurs at a younger age and commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. Most tumors have a balanced translocation (11;22) involving EWSRI gene and FL1 gene.

Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen in radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

 

Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumour occurring mainly in long bones. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumour. On histology presence of "chicken wire calcification" is pathognomic.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

 

Adamantinoma is a rare malignant tumour. Most cases appear in the lower extremities and classically in the tibial diaphysis. It is most often seen in the second to fourth decade of life. The patient usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling. X-ray shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopy shows epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. Intralesional or marginal excision causes local recurrence so complete excision of the tumour is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A barber aged 42 years presented with a healed ulcer as below, over the lower medial aspect of the right leg. On examination, he has varicose veins on both his legs. What is the most likely type of ulcer he had?
questions.solution:
The history of varicose veins and the presence of an ulcer at the lower 1/3rd of the leg with eczema and pigmentation is characteristic of a venous ulcer.

Venous ulcers are due to chronic venous insufficiency and are particularly seen in the area between the muscles of the calf and ankle. They are accompanied by lipodermatosclerosis and hemosiderosis(If these features are not present then the ulcer is probably not of venous origin). Ambulatory venous hypertension is the most acceptable theory in the pathophysiology of venous ulcers. It has a sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by slough and exudate. Marjolin’s ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma seen in chronic long-standing venous ulcers.

Management of venous ulcers:

  • Bisgaard's regimen
    1. Education
    2. Elevation of the affected limb to reduce the edema
    3. Elastic compression stockings - The ideal interface pressure in venous ulceration is 35-40 mmHg.
    4. Evaluation
  • 4 layer bandaging system comprising of:
    • Orthopedic wool
    • Cotton crepe
    • Elastic bandage - first compressive layer
    • Cohesive bandage - second compressive layer
  • Antibiotics are given only if the wound is infected.
  • Regular dressing.
  • Medical management by oral pentoxifylline is considered which helps in reducing the viscosity and improving circulation. 
  • Surgery- ulcer excision with pinch mesh grafting has a good outcome and helps in preventing recurrence. 
Type of Ulcer Ischaemic/ Arterial Venous Neuropathic Tuberculous  
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits. The lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, is never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla, and groin, tip or anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
Characteristics

Deep, penetrating the fascia exposes the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, with irregular margin tenderness, and hyperesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. painless, punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, and undermined with pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base.
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes enlarged, usually the vertical group, the ulcer is recurrent, forms again after healing

Dry, warm foot

Loss of sensation, vibration, and reflexes.

Bony deformities may be present.

 Regional lymph nodes are enlarged, non-tender, matted

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department by her mother saying she noted some abnormality in her genital area. On examination, there was presence of pubic and axillary hair. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pubic and axillary hair in a five-year-old girl is suggestive of precocious puberty and 17-Hydroxylase deficiency is least likely to cause it. 

In 17-hydroxylase deficiency, patients are unable to synthesize sex hormones. Females are normal at birth and present with complaints of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics in later life. The affected males are incompletely virilized and present as phenotypic females but undescended testes are usually palpable in the inguinal region.

In both 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiencies, the respective precursors to the hormones are shunted to the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in all the signs and symptoms of androgen excess. Female babies are typically born with signs of virilization like ambiguous genitalia characterized by clitoral enlargement and labial fusion. Whereas, the males have normal-appearing genitalia at birth and present at 2 to 4 years with precocious puberty like early pubarche, a growth spurt, and adult body odour.

Since this child is having features of ambiguous genitalia and virilization, it is unlikely that she would have a 17-Hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Similar lesions was present near the anal canal.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is of Condyloma Accuminata.

Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

  • Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor.
  • It is more common in males than in females.
  • Most common site:
    • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
    • In females: Posterior fourchette
  • On histology koilocytes are seen.

These are squamous epithelial cells which have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, perinuclear halo.

  • Most of these warts resolve spontaneously.
  • Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptor 7 and 8

questions.text: A patient with breast carcinoma presents with swelling of ankle for the past 3 months. Urine examination shows heavy proteinuria and haematuria. Renal biopsy is likely to reveal
questions.solution:
A kidney biopsy in a patient with features of nephrotic syndrome secondary to carcinomas would most probably reveal membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous glomerulonephritis:

  • Primary/idiopathic membranous glomerulonephritis
  • Secondary membranous glomerulonephritis
    • Infection: Hepatitis B and C, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis, leprosy, filariasis
    • Cancer: Breast, colon, lung, stomach, kidney, esophagus, neuroblastoma
    • Drugs: Gold, mercury, penicillamine, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents, probenecid
    • Autoimmune diseases: Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, primary biliary cirrhosis, dermatitis herpetiformis, bullous pemphigoid, myasthenia gravis, Sjogren’s syndrome, Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.
    • Other systemic diseases: Fanconi’s syndrome, sickle cell anemia, diabetes, Crohn’s disease, sarcoidosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, Weber-Christian disease, angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia.
  • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.
  • Most common nephropathy associated with malignancy.
  • The highest incidence of renal vein thrombosis.
  • Light microscopy shows uniform thickening of the basement membrane along with peripheral capillary loops. 
  • Immunofluorescence shows diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3.
  • Pathological findings:
    • Light microscopy: Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along the peripheral capillary loops
    • Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and c3.
    • Electron microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium,

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is not used for brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for systemic radiotherapy.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which a radioactive source is placed directly into or near the target tissue to deliver localized radiation treatment. It is commonly used for treating various types of cancer.

Other options:

A) Iodine-125: This radioactive isotope is commonly used in brachytherapy for treating prostate cancer. It emits low-energy gamma rays that can effectively target and treat the cancerous tissue.

C) Cobalt-60: This isotope is not typically used in brachytherapy but rather in external beam radiation therapy. Cobalt-60 emits high-energy gamma rays and is commonly used in radiation therapy machines called cobalt units or teletherapy units. These units deliver radiation from outside the body, targeting the tumor.

D) Iridium-192: This is a commonly used radioactive isotope in brachytherapy. It emits high-energy gamma rays and is used for treating various types of cancer, such as cervical, prostate, and breast cancer. Iridium-192 is often used in temporary brachytherapy, where the radioactive source is temporarily placed in the body and then removed after a specific period of treatment.

In summary, while Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are commonly used in brachytherapy, Cobalt-60 is primarily used in external beam radiation therapy. Iodine-131 is not typically used in brachytherapy but has other medical applications, such as thyroid cancer treatment and diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A 45 -year-old presented with severe pain in the right leg below the knee. He had a history of restricted ambulation and prolonged bed rest due to his severe back pain. He has no other comorbidities or history of smoking. On examination of his right calf, discoloration and significantly increased girth are noted and are shown below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Deep vein thrombosis due to immobilization and venous stasis is the most likely cause.

Deep Vein Thrombosis:

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins and less often in the proximal veins of the thigh and pelvis. Deep vein thrombosis is caused due to 3 broad categories of risk factors (Virchow's triad):

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulability 
  • Endothelial injury/dysfunction

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Muscular violence
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Treatment

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation  

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume which is maximum at 34 weeks of gestation.

The volume of amniotic fluid each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum and thereafter it starts declining till term. 

Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the following:

Pathway  Volume in ml
Fetal urination +1000 
Fetal swallowing -750
Fetal lung fluid secretion +350
Intramembranous flow across fetal vessels on the placental surface -400

Early in pregnancy, amnionic fluid arises mainly from a transudate of plasma either from the fetal skin or across the uterine decidua and placenta. Fetal urine production becomes a major component in the second trimester.

Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score.

questions.text: The image shown below is a pathognomonic finding in Psoriasis. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicting the Subungual oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.  

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature.

Image of Thinning of Nails.Most common sign Of Lichen Planus of the nails

Image of Dorsal Nail Pterygium.
It is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. Fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: What is the preferred management of the condition given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dermoid cyst and the preferred management of this condition is surgical excision.

A dermoid cyst is a benign developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. They are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair.

They are considered to be congenital and usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. They occur most commonly on the head and neck in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

They present as a flesh-coloured, dome-shaped, firm, deep-seated, subcutaneous nodule. They are usually asymptomatic, non-pulsatile, and non-compressible. 

On ultrasound, they show a well-defined homogenous and hypoechoic cystic lesion. They have the potential to grow over time and extend intracranially or intraspinally. MRI is the preferred means of revealing evidence of intracranial or intraspinal extension. 

Because most dermoid cysts grow over time, complete surgical excision without disruption of the cyst wall is the recommended management.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, history and hysteroscopy are suggestive of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of adhesion within the endometrial cavity. It is also called uterine synechiae and can be asymptomatic tiny bands or can completely or almost completely obliterate the endometrial cavity. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous uterine curettage, tuberculous endometritis, pelvic radiation, or endometrial ablation.

It causes secondary amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, habitual abortion and infertility depending upon the extent of uterine cavity obliteration.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Mild: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) may show honeycomb or moth-eaten appearance. Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions.

The image below shows a moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is of a  _____.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Taylor brace.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Taylor brace is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support your spine whilst standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

Other options:

Option A: Boston brace is a type of thoraco-lumbosacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower.   

Option B: Milwaukee brace also known as cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis or CTLSO is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with high thoracic and cervical spine curves.

Option D: Anterior spinal hyperextension (ASHE) brace is an anterior spinal hyperextension brace used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending.
