questions.text: A baby assessed five minutes after birth is found to be blue with irregular gasping respiration. The heart rate is 50 beats/min, and a grimace is seen in response to stimulation with a catheter in the nostrils. On assessing the baby's muscle tone, you note that there is some flexion of the extremities. The APGAR score for this newborn is
questions.solution:
The APGAR score of this newborn is 4.

In this baby:

  • Colour blue - score 0
  • HR < 100/min - score 1
  • Grimace - score 1
  • Some flexion of extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

Thus total score in this patient is 4

SIGN   0 1 2
A: Appearance (Colour) Blue, pale Body pink, extremities blue Completely pink 
P: Pulse (Heart rate) Absent Below 100 Over 100
G: Grimace
(Response to catheter in nostril)		 No response Grimace Cough or sneeze 
A: Activity(Muscle tone) Limp Some flexion of extremities Active motion 
R: Respiratory effort Absent  Slow, irregular Good, crying
  • At 1 minute and 5 minutes after complete birth of the infant (disregarding the cord and placenta), the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated, and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • A total score of 10 indicates an infant in the best possible condition.
  • An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

The first stage of labour consists of two phases :

  1. Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).
  2. Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is termed as a prolonged latent phase of labour. Bed rest is the preferred treatment unless there is any indication for expediting the delivery.

The presence of false labour pains for a long time may be confused with a prolonged latent phase. The differences between them include

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in a prolonged latent phase. There is no indication of the cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phases due to the risk of infections.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What is the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.

During early puerperium, sloughing of the decidual tissue causes vaginal discharge which is known as lochia. Most women experience an increase in the amount of bleeding at 7-14 days secondary to the sloughing of the eschar on the placental site. But the average duration of lochial discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days.

The lochial discharge appears as follows:

Name Colour Timing after delivery Content
Lochia rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink After 3-4 days

WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms
Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat cells

The persistence of red lochia beyond one week might be an indicator of uterine subinvolution. The presence of an offensive odour, large pieces of tissue or blood clots in lochia, excessive or absence of lochia might be a sign of infection.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note fixed, tender, retroverted uterus and tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea with a fixed retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas most likely suffering from endometriosis.

For minimal disease, medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases, oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser and resection of endometrioma can be done. Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) to control pain .Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Identify the obstetric grip performed in the picture.
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is a pelvic grip.

Leopold's manoeuvres help assess the fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head. They are as follows:

  1. Fundal grip (first Leopold): Assesses the uterine fundus.
    • Helps in the identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
    • The breech is felt as a large, irregular mass. The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Lateral grip (second Leopold):  Assesses fetal orientation.
    • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
    • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure. The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts.
  3. Pawlik's grip/ 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold): Assesses the presenting part.
    • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
    • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.
  4. Deep pelvic grip/ 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold): Assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head.
    • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
    • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate.

In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below. 

The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative
